165369414.name: Jose Clemente Orozco\'s best mural.
165369414.author: a TripAdvisor user
165369414.reviewBody: Man on fire, great. The entire building is beautiful. They also display the history of the state of Jalisco as well as an amazing map of old Guadalajara and the sorrounding counties.The fact that if you do not go in they do not allow you to use the rest romos.

163287474.name: Nice feel in the area
163287474.author: a TripAdvisor user
163287474.reviewBody: This building is surrounded by a pedestrian walking mall and brings the locals out on the weekends. It has a real Mexican flavor in the area and was nice to stroll in. I was invited to a reception at the Cabanas so my experience would be quite different than someone just walking through the empty buildings. As a venue for a reception - fantastic! Music, drinks, atmosphere. As a tourist just visiting the large concrete building with gigantic murals inside (all quite violent and dark) - not so interesting.

163197674.name: History in the Walls
163197674.author: a TripAdvisor user
163197674.reviewBody: This is a must to visit. The inside corridor is the main attraction. You will witness the works of famous painter Jose Clemente Orozco. Make sure your cameras is charged up for taking a lot of pictures.

163110125.name: Stunning Murals
163110125.author: a TripAdvisor user
163110125.reviewBody: An excellent example of Spanish Colonial architecture, with an entire building painted by Orozco (on the inside, in mural form). There are some permanent collections but they are not extensive, and special exhibitions are always present, but the murals are the real treat - you can spend a good hour just studying each one in detail.\nIt\'s a good idea to read about Orozco and his work beforehand, as the guides (pamphlets) are not too helpful, the people however are pretty informative if you want to spend the money.

162223746.name: It is a MUST to visit in Guadalajara
162223746.author: a TripAdvisor user
162223746.reviewBody: It is a beautiful colonial building with a very rich architecture from that time. If you take your tour with a guide from the main door you will enjoy more the visit.... and PLEASE watch carefully the murals of JOSE CLEMENTE OROZCO, specially the "man of fire" at the very center of the complex.

161500783.name: Historical site
161500783.author: a TripAdvisor user
161500783.reviewBody: Very cool, if you like huge Mexican rchitecture, this place is huge, and there is a lot to see, art, and you learn a lot just by reading a lot of the exhibits, there....

158915322.name: Worth the trip to Guadalajara
158915322.author: a TripAdvisor user
158915322.reviewBody: You should go first to the Palacio de Gobierno and see the 2 murals they have there of Orozco...after that go to Hospicio Cabanas:  the place in itself is amazing but when you see Orozco\'s murals there is the grand finale for your visit to Guadalajara.  Make sure you have one of the guides in there, very knowledgeable, enthusiastic, friendly people.  Don\'t  miss it!

156126468.name: Interesting murals
156126468.author: a TripAdvisor user
156126468.reviewBody: The murals (which are on the UNESCO world heritage list) were worth a visit - though the subject matter (fire and brimstone!) may not appeal to everyone. The rest of the site was largely vacant when we visited which was a shame.

155618645.name: Confusing if you don\'t have a guide
155618645.author: a TripAdvisor user
155618645.reviewBody: Don\'t even attempt to make sense of these murals unless you have a guide or guidebook.  The murals are spectacular but spectacularly inscrutible unless you understand the imagery.

155618536.name: Cultural and Historic place
155618536.author: a TripAdvisor user
155618536.reviewBody: This cultural and historic place was once a hospital and a orphanage  that beside the impressive murals and frescoes, is beautiful itself for its architecture. The master piece is the Man of Fire by Jose Clemente Orozco. This place is very emblematic in this city so you should definitely visit it but bring your students ID (for discounts) and get in early. I recommend the tours guides because they really get you in the history of this museum.

154123776.name: Nice place, but nothing going on here on the day we visited
154123776.author: a TripAdvisor user
154123776.reviewBody: Nice place, well preserved. However, did not get to see anything that day as they were preparing for a concert for the Mexican President; so no other Exhibits were going on.

153768720.name: Royal
153768720.author: a TripAdvisor user
153768720.reviewBody: A very majestic building of huge proportions offers the works of Orosco at his finest.  Many foreign exhibits are show here as well. It can take a few visits to see it all.

153403491.name: Historic orphanage beautifully refurbished
153403491.author: a TripAdvisor user
153403491.reviewBody: Beautiful old building with stunning murals and lovely patios. A very nice place to wander. The tour guide was a little long-winded, but you can duck in and out of the tour.

153341056.name: Interesting, though limited
153341056.author: a TripAdvisor user
153341056.reviewBody: the murals are certainly the star of the show at this museum. Bring alone your student ID for a hefty discount! much of the exhibits seemed to be closed, but the few that were open were very interesting and well planned.

153331922.name: Wonderful Museum
153331922.author: a TripAdvisor user
153331922.reviewBody: The museum offers a great variety of murals and other exhibits, you can easily spend 2 hours there. It is not boring at all because you can admire the murals on the roof. I really enjoyed the museum; I would definitely recommend a visit.

153325423.name: Seems like a must for Guadalajara
153325423.author: a TripAdvisor user
153325423.reviewBody: The murals are great, but I liked the structure itself even better.  It\'s a beautiful space.  We went first thing on a Saturday morning and it was nearly deserted.  For a short time...

152955736.name: ask at the desk for an english tour
152955736.author: a TripAdvisor user
152955736.reviewBody: We were there on Tuesday which we found out is free day. The 57 murals in the capilla mayor are wonderful. The painter was also an engineer so there are many 3D and visual illustions. Have a staff member show them to you. Definitely a ighlight of our stay in the City.

151224827.name: Slightly disappointed
151224827.author: a TripAdvisor user
151224827.reviewBody: the permanent art exhibition was good without being outstanding. I was slightly disappointed by most of the murals by Orozco, except the man of fire.  there was an excellent temporary exhibition.\n\nIn the square outside outside there were some wonderful sculptures.

150701919.name: Must see in Guadalajara
150701919.author: a TripAdvisor user
150701919.reviewBody: The hospicio means orphanage in Spanish. This used to be , among many different uses over its LONG history, a home for poor children. RIGHT next door is the Mercado Libertad which is a must see. And near by Centro Joyero. I love visiting the Zhispicio. You are charged extra - small amt. To take ojotos but it is eorth it plus these spaces need a lot of maintenance!

149104990.name: Very interesting murals
149104990.author: a TripAdvisor user
149104990.reviewBody: I liked murals of Clemente Orozco, they are impressive. It\'s a great building. It is a must in Guadalajara

148977135.name: Take a tour guide for frescos interpretation .
148977135.author: a TripAdvisor user
148977135.reviewBody: Frescos and tour guide. It\'s history too. Hardly anyone there at the time which made it even more special.

148861243.name: Amazing
148861243.author: a TripAdvisor user
148861243.reviewBody: A great place to visit, full of culture. It\'s a must go.\nThe convent itself is gorgeous and the paintings inside are a wonder.

147063308.name: Must see the murals at Instituto Cultural Cabanas
147063308.author: a TripAdvisor user
147063308.reviewBody: The Instituto Cultural Cababas has beautiful art of disturbing scenes.  Recommended viewing is to lay on the benches to take in the ceiling murals.  Then tour the galleries and courtyards for even more culturally important artworks.  The architecture is also gorgeous.

146877016.name: Orozco\'s finest
146877016.author: a TripAdvisor user
146877016.reviewBody: This one thing in Guadalajara you CANT miss. A guide (from the Instituto) will show you more than 10 books.

145730701.name: ONE OF THE "MUST SEE" IN GUADALAJARA
145730701.author: a TripAdvisor user
145730701.reviewBody: Largest colonial building in Iberoamerica. Really well kept. Part of seeing downtown.  It is really Majestic.  Of course you will not see this only, you also need to see the theater, the market next to it, ans of course the Cathedral.  You really should see it! and take some time to have a coffee or lunch/dinner on this part of town.

145078989.name: If you love art, museums & architecture - you will like this... otherwise
145078989.author: a TripAdvisor user
145078989.reviewBody: I found the murals to be interesting, very large and full of meaning (if only I knew what the meanings were behind each of them; I didn\'t take the time to read the pamphlet), however this site wouldn\'t be at the top of my \'most interesting things to do list\'. It was nice to walk around the site and see the building\'s architecture as well. For those who like this type of thing, I suspect you won\'t be disappointed, for those thinking it\'s more than just a group of nice buildings with some cool murals in one of them...  you may be disappointed; I\'d still visit, as you can be in and out within 20 minuts or so, and as said, it is interesting. *I am not much for museums overall, so please take this into account when assessing my review :-)

144896251.name: Huge expectations, disappointing
144896251.author: a TripAdvisor user
144896251.reviewBody: If you are an Orozo fan, this could be your paradise.  However, as Guadlajara\'s only World Heritage Site, I expected more.  It is a huge building with very interesting history.  But now, what you are entering to look at are the Orozco\'s in the first hall and whatever exhibition is happening in the auxilary hall.  You can walk around the whole place but the rest is just....a building.  I was lucky that the auxilary had a great exhibit by a local artist, Rodo Padilla.  Of course, you have to go see it but don\'t get your expectations up.

144016286.name: Amazing murals of Jose Clemente Orozco
144016286.author: a TripAdvisor user
144016286.reviewBody: Amazing murals of Jose Clemente Orozco, one of the most important artists in Mexico decorates the ceilings and walls impressively. Very pleased to visit this museum, the biggest one in town

142314166.name: Beautiful murals. Worth a visit.
142314166.author: a TripAdvisor user
142314166.reviewBody:
No touristic trip to Guadalajara is complete without a visit to see Orozco's murals here.
The price seemed a little high for entry at 70 pesos per person plus a 30-peso fee for using a camera, but you'll be glad you paid it once you see the inside.
They did not offer a guide to us to explain the history and interpretations of the murals, so that was disappointing. But we understood some of what was depicted and knew the story of Orozco, so we were not left completely unaware.
If you go, just ask for a guide at the entrance (something we found out was available after we left).

141156473.name: Gorgeous old historical building
141156473.author: a TripAdvisor user
141156473.reviewBody: We went on the walking tour so we learned a lot more of the history of this building than we would have otherwise.  The artwork by Orozco decorates the ceilings and walls spectacularly.  The building started as a convent, then becambe an orphanage before being converted to the Cultural Cabanas.

139703361.name: See this.
139703361.author: a TripAdvisor user
139703361.reviewBody: Jose Clemente Orozco is considered one of the great artists/muralists in Mexican history.  Make sure to get a guided tour to describe the events and politics that bring so much meaning to the murals in this location.

138105786.name: Amazing
138105786.author: a TripAdvisor user
138105786.reviewBody: One of the places you cannot miss to visit when you come to GDL. Full of Jos\u00e9 Clemente Orozco mural it is just astonishing!!! Reserve at least 2 hours and many pictures to enjoy the place.

136944027.name: verygood  paintings
136944027.author: a TripAdvisor user
136944027.reviewBody: It is a very good spot for enjoying the day.Centrally located with nice paintings and historical sculptures.

136334653.name: Being found with the past.
136334653.author: a TripAdvisor user
136334653.reviewBody: A place with a lot of history in the city. It is " a must" to visit. You will be surprised with its greatness, its several yards, and rooms in which you can found art exhibitions. You would have a wonderful experience there. I highly recommend. \nRemember to bring your camera with you, you will catch great pics there.

135934495.name: Amazing!
135934495.author: a TripAdvisor user
135934495.reviewBody: We have been all over Mexico since we return every year ( or more) for research. Guadalajara is not my favorite city, but seeing the paintings by Orozco is amazing in person. Truly amazing. Breath taking. Worth the visit and then head to the Palacio to see more of his work.

135690482.name: Bit of a Letdown
135690482.author: a TripAdvisor user
135690482.reviewBody:
I may sound like a stupid gringo for giving this a "3 star" review, however, this place just didn't do it for me.  Obviously the Orozco mural is the highlight here -- absolutely incredible and beautiful.   There were 2 other exhibits going at this time -- one was a Cirque de Soleil exhibit and the other was contemporary art (which, is an acquired taste!).    

The Cirque de Soleil exhibit was kindof cool but, I didn't travel to Mexico looking for something like that.    

After looking at the Cirque de Soleil exhibit, I headed towards the contemporary art exhibits -- which took about 2 minutes to look at....and then, I was like...is that it??   And yes, that WAS it.   It's just that there isn't much to this place....

The building is beautiful and does have history but i left wanting more.  

Entrance fee is roughly 80 MXN.  DIscounts for seniors are available.

134586805.name: a must when you visit guadalajara
134586805.author: a TripAdvisor user
134586805.reviewBody: also good to to take a look, the cathedral and the teatro degollado

133946044.name: Murals and paintings, cultural enrichment!
133946044.author: a TripAdvisor user
133946044.reviewBody: I like the way they take care of this places very clean and well maintained. I recomend visiting this place if you ever travel to guadalajara.

133912694.name: Good for a walk
133912694.author: a TripAdvisor user
133912694.reviewBody: It\'s a great building to walk around. The architectural site is beautiful. If you want to take pictures, you have to pay extra if you are a tourist.

133333430.name: Interesting
133333430.author: a TripAdvisor user
133333430.reviewBody: This was thee only Guad historical sites we visited that we paid entrance fee for, buildings and mural are very nice, I did not particularly enjoyed the rest of it.

132509882.name: Unique paitings
132509882.author: a TripAdvisor user
132509882.reviewBody: REally nice place, and the murals are amazing in good contition and you have this tables to lay down and admire the murals on the roof. It\' also very cheap, excelent price for value. The building is also very pretty.\n\nHighly recomended, you only can see murals like these in Mexico Cty and California (USA).

132267693.name: What history!
132267693.author: a TripAdvisor user
132267693.reviewBody: This is a good place to learn a little about the history of GDL.

131867564.name: Nice old part of tradition in Guadalajara
131867564.author: a TripAdvisor user
131867564.reviewBody: Nice place to visit and get acquainted with the city and its traditions. Busy cultural center and centric to all other tour facilities.

131705672.name: Saw young musicians practicing their craft
131705672.author: a TripAdvisor user
131705672.reviewBody: The students were intent in their efforts; you have the opportunity to view their eagerness to succeed via a glass pane

131417551.name: Incredible murals
131417551.author: a TripAdvisor user
131417551.reviewBody: Truly a visual marvel steeped in deep and compelling history.

130362486.name: Incredible paintings
130362486.author: a TripAdvisor user
130362486.reviewBody: Well it is known for the paintings but the many courtyards also showed an exhibition of painted barrels and it was nice to stroll around the convent with many flowers.

129070592.name: Awesome murals by Orozco
129070592.author: a TripAdvisor user
129070592.reviewBody: Very pleased to visit, murals by Orozco are truly amazing

128327414.name: A great display of public art!
128327414.author: a TripAdvisor user
128327414.reviewBody: Mexico\'s muralists painted in gargantuan scale for public consumption, so the Hospicio\'s large rooms are the perfect place to display Jose Orozco\'s murals.  See photos and read more about other worthwhile sites within blocks here:  http://antonio1028.wordpress.com/2012/04/22/guadalajaras-heartbeat/

127753935.name: Sore neck but well worth it!
127753935.author: a TripAdvisor user
127753935.reviewBody: Our tour guide was great and funny it was conducted in Spanish.  We happened to go on a Tuesday which happened to be free, not sure if it is every Tuesday or just because it was Holy week.  Artist Jose Clemente Orozco was a contempoary to Diego Rivera, but was alot more political.  His work is beautiful and well worth the tour due to the history and viewing angles involved, some of the works change depending on the angle of viewing, the tourguide does a great job of pointing out these changes.  So worth the money!

126922964.name: Gorgeous Building
126922964.author: a TripAdvisor user
126922964.reviewBody:
This is such an incredibly beautiful building.
We thought the entrance price was a bit too steep, so the rest of my family waited outside and only I went in.  I loved the building but other than the murals in the centre, there wasn't anything much else to see and most areas were locked off.  There was one room with some photographs of the orphan children who once lived here, which I did enjoy.

For the entrance price I was not even offered a pamphlet, but did find one later on in the gift shop.  Other groups were getting a tour in Spanish, and if you had a tour you may get a lot more out of your visit and find it worthwhile for the price.  

It is free to visit the murals at the University.

126651698.name: Don\'t miss this exceptional site
126651698.author: a TripAdvisor user
126651698.reviewBody: The murals inside the main building are exceptional and were a highlight of our trip to Guadalajara.

126096093.name: Impressive
126096093.author: a TripAdvisor user
126096093.reviewBody: Hospicio Caba\u00f1as is a very impressive building in downtown Guadalajara, that also serves as site for temporary art exhibits. It also is the location of the famous murals by Jose Clemente Orozco, one of the great Mexican muralists of the XX century. Definetely worth visiting. Next door is one of the largest markets in Mexico (Mercado Libertad, a.k.a. San Juan de Dios) where you can find anything ... mexican crafts, hats, leather, charro outfits, pets, witchcraft items, fruits&veggies, ... warning: hold on to your wallet, it is crowded and very popular

125702619.name: A must in Guadalajara
125702619.author: a TripAdvisor user
125702619.reviewBody: The murals are a memorable experience and a lesson in Mexican history. We were fortunate to have a guide whose passion and insight gave us an understanding that we would not have had otherwise.  This guide was also the one who guided President Obama when he visited the Instituto Cultural Cabanas. We discovered Orosco through the unforgettable The Man of Fire and the other 57 murals.

125364308.name: Great murals
125364308.author: a TripAdvisor user
125364308.reviewBody: The inside dome of the Instituto has some of the most stunning murals you will see anywhere in Mexico. Also, a great bookstore where one can buy prints, and several workshops where artists and students are in the process of creating contemporary work or restoring older work. A must visit in Guadalajara.

125188996.name: unique
125188996.author: a TripAdvisor user
125188996.reviewBody: it is a must, the building and the paintings represent a important of Mexico and colony period

124975343.name: A must-go!
124975343.author: a TripAdvisor user
124975343.reviewBody: The Hospicio not only is a beautiful building and a typical sight in Guadalajara, but it also houses the great mural paintings of Jose Clemente Orozco.

124692285.name: Do the English language tour
124692285.author: a TripAdvisor user
124692285.reviewBody: This place is beautiful but there\'s not a lot to see other than the amazing Orozco murals. The first time we went we were a little disappointed, but we went again recently. Due to a review I read (probably on Tripadvisor) we asked for the English tour. It was really fascinating to learn more about the murals, which are so dramatic but not necesarily obvious. The guide was excellent and worked just for a tip. It made it a very meaningful experience.

124587015.name: A must see sight for tourists and locals
124587015.author: a TripAdvisor user
124587015.reviewBody: What Mexico is really all about: culture and architecture!

124303479.name: Beautiful Building
124303479.author: a TripAdvisor user
124303479.reviewBody: Look for the art expositions that are there, It is one of the best places in the city to look for art, It has hosted lot of official events.

124129861.name: Orozco murals
124129861.author: a TripAdvisor user
124129861.reviewBody: The murals are fantastic and the exhibitions are usually very good as well.

124021596.name: Historic UNESCO building
124021596.author: a TripAdvisor user
124021596.reviewBody: full of Orosco murals. Planned and built to be an orphanage, turned into a hospital during the war of Independence from Spain. Also see the unique bronze statues outside.

123704110.name: Impressive historic site
123704110.author: a TripAdvisor user
123704110.reviewBody: Took a guided tour of this amazing building and I was stunned with all the paintings and the overall architecture of the Hospicio. Amazing to see the one painting in the main room "move" as you walked around the aisle. I definitely recommend this gem to anyone visiting Guadalajara!

123692862.name: Amazing building and history
123692862.author: a TripAdvisor user
123692862.reviewBody: A beautiful building that used to be an orphanage and now is a cultural center. It has paintings on it\'s cealing from world known mexican artist Jose Clemente Orozco. A must see when visiting Guadalajara.

123416687.name: A must-see in Guadalajara
123416687.author: a TripAdvisor user
123416687.reviewBody: Besides the famous Orozco paintings there are many little courtyards with some exhibitions. When we went it was decorated wine barrels, quite interesting.\nAlso not to be missed are the weird brass seats just outside the Hospicio. Easy to not see because there might be things on the plaza like the ice-skating ring for example.

123362220.name: unbeivable painting
123362220.author: a TripAdvisor user
123362220.reviewBody: well worth the 70 peso per person entry free 30 peso extra for your camara, which is a eccentiale. this building is know as the cisten chapple of mexico and the 57 painting by jose clemente orozco are a must see in guadalajara

123266330.name: Hospicio Cabanas
123266330.author: a TripAdvisor user
123266330.reviewBody: It is great...everyone who visits the city should go and stroll through it and the surrounding area.

123266041.name: Cabanas
123266041.author: a TripAdvisor user
123266041.reviewBody: Liked it better when it was an orphanage and the bull ring was in front of it...but now there are lots of cultural activities there and days could be spend going through all the patios and rooms there.

123076568.name: A must for art/culture lovers!
123076568.author: a TripAdvisor user
123076568.reviewBody: Make sure you take the guided tour of the main hall. The hidden 3-D effects of the paintings are jaw-dropping!

122886018.name: the best of Guadalajara
122886018.author: a TripAdvisor user
122886018.reviewBody: Lovely place in Guadalajara, Is just to be an orphanage but is now a museum, inside you can see all this frescos of Jose Clemente Orozco, the most famous one is \u201cel hombre en llamas\u201d, the architecture is impeccable, from the Colonial times. Inside you have all this different \u201cpatios\u201d where now days they use to perform concerts and all sort of events, the museum is all around the patios and they normally have different expositions with contemporary art, or photography, etc. is very interesting because you get to see great art in a great place... very recommended when you come to Mexico. Definitely a \u201cmost\u201d

122636033.name: A must
122636033.author: a TripAdvisor user
122636033.reviewBody: If you are in town visiting and are looking for emblematic and historic sites, then Hospicio Cabanas is a place to visit. It offers gorgeous architectural features as well as a showcase of one Mexico\'s most famous muralist Jose Clemento Orozco. Don\u00b4t forget to bring a camera, the small fee for camera usage is worth it, believe me it is....

122407249.name: Orozco Murals
122407249.author: a TripAdvisor user
122407249.reviewBody: Beautiful. Highly recommend stopping here. The murals on the ceiling are amazing. So much to look at!

122163533.name: Listen the history.
122163533.author: a TripAdvisor user
122163533.reviewBody: the murals are incredible, it\'s a magic place and a very important Siqueiro\'s art work.  You can\'t miss it.  And pay the guidance if you want to understand the importance of that beautiful place.

122046009.name: Always worthwhile...
122046009.author: a TripAdvisor user
122046009.reviewBody: Very impressive murals by the famous muralist Jose Clemente Orozco...some of his best work. There is almost always an interest exhibit there...it\'s one of the largest venues for art shows in Guadalajara. If you\'re looking for a book on Mexican history, art or popular culture, they have the best bookstore in town.

122032574.name: Worth a visit...
122032574.author: a TripAdvisor user
122032574.reviewBody: Instituto Cultural Cabanas and Hospicio Cabanas are the same place. A beautiful building with a major work by the great muralist Orozco. If you are interested in books on Mexican art or history, they have the best bookstore in town for those topics. There are frequently special exhibitions. Parking is a bit difficult when events are well attended.

121900886.name: Confusing for an anglophone
121900886.author: a TripAdvisor user
121900886.reviewBody:
I found it difficult to get any useful information from the staff.  I think I missed out because there were no written materials in english and I didn't have time to research in advance.

The murals are impressive.

The location is excellent.  Just a short walk to interesting cathedrals and public buldings.

121367020.name: Orozco!!
121367020.author: a TripAdvisor user
121367020.reviewBody: This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Guadalajara, a city almost razed by throughtless "development" and houses Orozco\'s impressive murals in what I suppose was the main church. They have mirrors so you can sit and study the incredible, opressive imagery.

121038029.name: Take in the whole area
121038029.author: a TripAdvisor user
121038029.reviewBody: The are was rather disquieting but the place is enormous and interesting

119958277.name: Excelent
119958277.author: a TripAdvisor user
119958277.reviewBody: Be sure to take the guide if you want to understand the extraordinary murals.

119462040.name: Amazing !!
119462040.author: a TripAdvisor user
119462040.reviewBody: You are living the old times of Guadalajara and Mexico country  when you are visiting this incredible place.

119312960.name: Orozco is a true master.
119312960.author: a TripAdvisor user
119312960.reviewBody: I been to Guadalajara many times and manage to mise this true treasure. Not this time, the work done by orozco is incredible. I would say this is a must for anybody coming to Guadalajara.

90714367.name: The history of Mexico in a series of murals.
90714367.author: a TripAdvisor user
90714367.reviewBody: These beautiful murals by Mexican artist, Jose Clemente Orozco, were the highlight of our trip to Guadalajara.  We enlisted an English-speaking guide by the ticket counter who gave us a detailed run-down of the history of the orphanage.  He also highlighted many important features in the murals that we wouldn\'t normally have noticed otherwise. After the tour, be sure to take the time to lie down on the benches and get a different of the murals.  What we liked the most about the murals were that they furthered our understanding and gave us some insight into Mexican history.\nOn an unrelated note, there is a tourist information right outside the museum in case you are looking for recommendations of other tourist attractions or nearby restaurants.

89507007.name: Best museum in town
89507007.author: a TripAdvisor user
89507007.reviewBody: Lovely museum, awesome paints of Jose Clemente Orozco! I really reccomend this place

87440530.name: Must see
87440530.author: a TripAdvisor user
87440530.reviewBody: This World Heritage site is a must see if you visit Guadalajara.

38261626.name: A Guadalajara Must-See
38261626.author: a TripAdvisor user
38261626.reviewBody: I absolutely adore Hospicio Cabanas.  Located at the end of a long pedestrian throughfare in downtown Guadalajara, it is a former hospital and orphanage.  Today, it is a vibrant arts center with an amazing Orozco mural "Man of Fire") as its centerpiece, a maze of beautiful courtyards and constantly-changing art exhibits.  There are guided tours in English and Spanish, but I think it\'s nice to take in this monolithic complex at your own pace.  My one gripe is with the ticket agent, who refused to sell me a ticket at the Mexican teacher rate, even though I was living in Guadalajara and teaching at a Mexican high school (and I showed her the proper credentials, of course).

6805597.name: GDL Cultural Spot
6805597.author: a TripAdvisor user
6805597.reviewBody:
ICC has wonderful Orozco murals.  They are definitely a must see.  When you enter the ICC you simply walk through the first courtyard and then you walk into the main part of the ICC.  The murals are overwhelming in size, and i recommend laying on the benches to get a more comfortable view of the ceiling murals.  One negative aspect is that their is no audio phone tour guide available for purchase like in Europe and the States.  The positive side is there are tour guides that walk into the main room where the murals are located every 20 minutes.  The simply walk to the center of the room and announce that they are about to give a guided tour.  The tour is only in Spanish. They give a very insightful tour, and I definitely recommend that you take advantage of their tour.  At the end, it is recommended that you give a tip, but it is not required.  In my group of 12 ppl, everyone gave 10 pesos. 

Besides,the Orozco murals there is a nice architecture section and it is full of students from the local university.  It takes about an hour to see the entire ICC.

3419024.name: Jose Clemente Orozco Paintings
3419024.author: a TripAdvisor user
3419024.reviewBody:
I just returned from a trip to Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico. While there I vistied the Hospicio Cabanas. Not only is the building a architectural marvel but it also houses 57 paintings by Jose Clemente Orozco. There is no way that I can do justice to this place. Orozco's paintings are fantastic. The main building of the Cabanas is completely covered with paintings from wall to ceilings. While I was there I asked for and got a private tour of the paintings. I didn't take any pictures because I didn't think I could do justice to this place. Instead I opted to purchase a book in the bookstore. On the tour the guide explained Orozco's play on perspective and his sarcastic attitude towards the Spanish conquest, the Catholic Church and the Mexican Government. If you view the paintings from different points in the room some of the paintings seem to change. Truly amazing. Its a must do.  But take my word for it, asking for a tour is the best way to see this. I've been there 3 times and got more this time by taking the tour then I ever could on my own.  Enjoy!  

Also don't forget to go to Palicio Del Gobierno near Catedral. It has the largest Orozco painting I have ever seen. This builidng has a painting of Miguel Hidalgo on the ceiling of one of the stairways. Its a wonderful work of art that depicts Miguel Hidalgo's the Mexican people's fight for freedom. Tours are also available at this location.

677243212.name: Good ambiance
677243212.author: a TripAdvisor user
677243212.reviewBody: We didn\u2019t go in a boat tour because the water looks dirty but they have a lot of puestesitos where you can buy array of souvenirs and comida chatarra. They have music and a really nice ambience to spend an afternoon at.

659989871.name: Very nice and relaxing place to visit
659989871.author: a TripAdvisor user
659989871.reviewBody: My wife and I came to Chapala to visit some long-time friends who have lived for seven years in this very large expat community on the north shore of Lake Chapala, the largest lake in Mexico, an hour south of Guadalajara.   We can see what attracts such a large number of Canadians, Americans, and Europeans to relocate here when they retire.   The weather is great all year round, the cost of living is extremely reasonable, and there is a plentiful assortment of things to do and people to get to know and do them with.

659736109.name: The lake is beautiful from afar....
659736109.author: a TripAdvisor user
659736109.reviewBody: Lake Chapala is very polluted but they are working getting it cleaned up.  Looking at the lake from mountainside is beautiful.  There are boats that will take you to the two small islands.  People don\'t swim or wade in this lake, nor do they wind surf or kayak.

658209860.name: Beautiful town, easy to reach on a bus
658209860.author: a TripAdvisor user
658209860.reviewBody: I wanted to see why so many expats were moving to Chapala. I went to the old buss station, and easily caught a direct bus to Chapala. I enjoyed it all. The promenade was gorgeous with all the jacarandas in full bloom. The flying men were just beginning their act so my timing was perfect. A very nice lunch overlooking the lake was reasonably priced. Also went to Ajijic by bus from Chapala, this is a lot quieter town. Artsy more than Mexican, really.

645954155.name: Ho hum trip
645954155.author: a TripAdvisor user
645954155.reviewBody: Took tour booked through Viator to Lake Chapala and Ajijic. We were the only ones. The driver was friendly. He did not have much knowledge of the areas he dropped us off at, no history, and not much conversation. So, trip was not that meaningful to us.

644108820.name: Polluted  and smelly
644108820.author: a TripAdvisor user
644108820.reviewBody: The largest lake in Mexico and unfortunately it looks best as one approaches  on the highway, looking down from a distance.

635508087.name: Nice lake
635508087.author: a TripAdvisor user
635508087.reviewBody: This town is a must see when visiting Guadalajara. It\'s a small town with a nice lake called Chapala. They sell souvenirs, garrafa ice cream, drinks and have some nice little restaurants around the area with good sea food.

632656356.name: Lovely area near Guadalajara.
632656356.author: a TripAdvisor user
632656356.reviewBody: Do take a tour at least to this beautiful and peaceful area.  Lots of expats living there.  No problem with finding persons whom speak English,   Lots to look at and purchase....

629944873.name: A must see
629944873.author: a TripAdvisor user
629944873.reviewBody: I was hesitant at first because I was aware that the area is a retirement haven, particularly for Canadians and Yanks and if I wanted to listen to English I could have stayed home. What a nice surprise on this Monday before All Hallows Eve to find the malecon empty of tourists and the lake at its highest level in a very long time. As the late morning wore on the number of school children increased as there was a career fair (?) set up under marquees which took a good amount of space on one side. Quite enjoyable. Opportunities to take a boat ride were presented but we declined, not my cup of tea. I did take up an offer to buy and eat a small plate of little fried fish with fresh lime and chili sauce from a elderly vendor. I have forgotten the name of this local delicacy and while not bad it\u2019s something I would probably not eat again. A cold beer did help. This place must buzz on the weekends so I crowds aren\u2019t your thing go during the week. It is about a 45 minute drive from GDL.

610995235.name: Boat Ride
610995235.author: a TripAdvisor user
610995235.reviewBody: Very wide lake, not very deep,  A little polluted.  Trip to Island was fun and interesting.  Fortunately the scorpions were not in season but the ants sure were.

609029482.name: Fabulous
609029482.author: a TripAdvisor user
609029482.reviewBody: The art, landscapes, architecture, people, food - It\'s all wonderful. PERIOD. Have a blast - we did!!!

603658706.name: Beautiful lake
603658706.author: a TripAdvisor user
603658706.reviewBody: Very large lake, Chapala great small town, very peaceful and charming. Great place to visit. \nA most to visit, good casual restaurant.

598016623.name: Excellent place to vacation
598016623.author: a TripAdvisor user
598016623.reviewBody: We came to Lake Chapala to escape the summer heat and found it to be cool and comfortable the 4 days we were there. The town is bustling with tourists, many of whom are Mexican. Since its founding in the 1800\'s it\'s been a place for tourists to escape the city, and Guadalajara is close enough to get there easily; the trip takes an hour or less by car. There is bus service but I recommend the car because of the difficulty of getting accurate schedules and departure/arrival locations. There are mariachis and other musicians on the malecon day and night; many good restaurants; our hotel, Toca Madera, was moderately priced, very comfortable, and the staff were very friendly. I don\'t recommend breakfast at that hotel as the service is slow and the menu limited. Other places in the area are much better. The items for sale along the malecon weren\'t of a high quality, but in nearby Ajijic there were many beautiful original pieces of handcrafted Mexican art. Ajijic is a short bus/cab/Uber ride away. I highly recommend going there. We would go back to Lake Chapala in a heartbeat.

593653103.name: Worth going to, at least for a day trip.
593653103.author: a TripAdvisor user
593653103.reviewBody: Ajijic and Chapala is definitely worth going to see, if only even for the day, especially Ajijic. There\'s a lot of fun little art galleries and great restaurants.

591156197.name: History and magic at its best
591156197.author: a TripAdvisor user
591156197.reviewBody: A great weekend getaway. The magic of the largest man made lake in Mexico. Steeped in history, local culture and the most friendly people anywhere.

590575608.name: Beautiful Lake
590575608.author: a TripAdvisor user
590575608.reviewBody: Lake Chapala is Mexico\'s largest natural lake the remnant of an ancient sea. A short drive (less than a hour) from Guadalajara, the lake area is very popular on the weekends. Because the towns of Chapala and Ajijic have such large populations of American and Canadian retirees, the variety of restaurants is unusually broad for small Mexican towns. English is widely spoken with any restaurants offering English language menus.  This lake is for looking, there is very little water sport activity. If you like Spring, the climate is nearly perfect.

584939370.name: A lovely change of pace with lovely scenery
584939370.author: a TripAdvisor user
584939370.reviewBody: It was lovely to get out into the countryside and visit beautiful Lake Chapala and nearby little town. We spent our time wandering the little streets and exploring.

583760833.name: Three Visits since 2011
583760833.author: a TripAdvisor user
583760833.reviewBody: I\u2019ve been to Chapala in 2012, 2016, and last week. My aunt and Uncle retired and have lived there in specifically Chula Vista since 2004.\n\nIt\u2019s a beautiful area and caters well to the snowbirds and gringos. Very inexpensive. It is not for everyone, and at age 58 I would not live there but I love to visit there.

581557539.name: One of the largest lakes in all Latin America
581557539.author: a TripAdvisor user
581557539.reviewBody: You can spend the entire day here. Take a panga to one of the islands for lunch, Walk the market area along the water, enjoy the restaurants o just relax watching the people. Something for everyone.

579011650.name: A beautiful lake and islands.
579011650.author: a TripAdvisor user
579011650.reviewBody: We had the best time because of our guide, Ofelia Alatorre. She is private. Her email is mexicoculturaltravel@gmail.com. She knows everything. We had a lovely lunch by the lake. We were hoping to catch a boat out to the island that used to be a prison and is haunted, but couldn\'t. I can\'t remember why - a holiday? There is another standard tourist island most people go to.\n\nFun on a sunny day. It\'s worth the short trip from Guadalajara.

574926878.name: Came to visit Ajijic and the Chapala lake area
574926878.author: a TripAdvisor user
574926878.reviewBody:
It’s beautiful here and you can’t beat the weather. It’s much less humid than other parts of Mexico. Humidity was about 40%, which makes even hot days a little more bearable. For some reason, it was a little smoggy, which made the lake not so picturesque. We stayed for several days and also had a great meal at Cocinart.

We also tried a local favorite drink called a Vampirito. Cuidado! They’re strong!

Chapala Area has great weather and reasonable prices. There are lots of “heat refugees” who come from other parts of Mexico to beat the heat, as well as a large US and Canadian expat community.

One of the unexpected delights is some of the gaited horses you’ll see along the shoreline. Beautiful and talented horses with skilled riders!

572265910.name: A nice diversion
572265910.author: a TripAdvisor user
572265910.reviewBody: Weekends are crowded   Great people watching.   The boat to the island Wes low key   A nice diversion from the city \n

571486976.name: Enjoyable day trip for the family
571486976.author: a TripAdvisor user
571486976.reviewBody: Great get away from Guadalajara. We took an uber out, and it wasn\'t that much money. We spent 6 hours at the lake and the surrounding areas. We did an hour tour on the water for 700 pesos, not sure if that was a lot or a little.\n\nAfter the hour on the water, we drove around to the surrounding towns to see the local sights and have some lunch. I really enjoyed it.

569892863.name: Gorgeous lake
569892863.author: a TripAdvisor user
569892863.reviewBody: Entertaining place to wander, eat, take in the sites and relax! Gorgeous little town center. Not the best place for shopping, prices were much higher for same items than in Guadalajara mercados.

567468597.name: A Great Get Away from Guadalajara
567468597.author: a TripAdvisor user
567468597.reviewBody:
Lago Chapala is about 1 hour south of Guadalajara and 45 minutes from the airport.
it is the biggest lake in Mexico, with nice scenery and at least one Island.
there are are two pueblos, Chapala and Ajijic on the Northern part of the lake, that
house a large expat community, of North Americans and serve as a weekend getaway for Guadalajara. these 2 towns are loaded with good restaurants, charming hotels,
spas and festivals. 
the lake itself only has small fishing boats!! why? shallow, or ???? they grow fruit, berries in this region, and the fruit is everywhere. delicious!!! there is one town in the mountains about an hour and a half by car, called Mazlamita, which is very charming and worth a side trip also.
so if you combine the lake with Guadalajara, your vacation will be a home run!!!

564083838.name: Great little boat ride!
564083838.author: a TripAdvisor user
564083838.reviewBody: We had never been to the Chapala lake and it was beautiful. The boat ride was about 45 minutes and it was relaxing even the kids enjoyed it. Nice little town.

562705306.name: Only 30 minutes from the airport - worth the stop!
562705306.author: a TripAdvisor user
562705306.reviewBody: As we were only in Guadalajara for 2.5 days, we didn\'t think we\'d have time to see the main city, Tequila and Lake Chapala.  Turns out we did because we hired a private driver from our hotel ($70/day).  On our last day, our driver picked us up from our hotel in Old Town Guadalajara and drove us out to Ajijic and Chapala for a half day, then took us directly to the airport which was only 30 minutes away.  (Ajijic and Chapala are only 15 minutes apart by car and Ajijic is much more quaint with better shopping.  If I were you I\'d hit Chapala first to see it, then go to Ajijic for lunch at one of the restaurants in the plaza). In Chapala we ate at a restaurant overlooking the lake, then walked along the boardwalk.  Unfortunately we didn\'t have time to take a boat out to the island though they didn\'t seem to be anything special and not many people were using them.  Overall, Chapala was cool to see but wasn\'t anything extraordinary.

555526148.name: A good day or weekend trip
555526148.author: a TripAdvisor user
555526148.reviewBody: First of all, it is not true that the lake is contaminated.  It is tested regularly by an engineer, and meets the standards of the US for swimming.  The problem is that there could be items left on the bottom from when the lake was very low and some of the land was farmed.  I see Mexican children swimming often in Ajijic.  Keep in mind this is not a resort area, although there are resort-type hotels with pools.  Many of the restaurants in Chapala, Ajijic, and other villages on the northern shore are excellent and very resaonably priced, and there are many more proportionally than in other small villages, due no doubt to the large expat population, of which I am one.  Due to the large artist population, there are many galleries, especially in Ajijic.  If one wants to see villages less populated by expats and more true to the fishing village atmosphere that the area is meant to be, go further west to San Juan Cosala and Jocotepec.

554273755.name: Attractive
554273755.author: a TripAdvisor user
554273755.reviewBody: but, for me, it didn\'t quite live up to all the hype that it gets.  The road to Guadalajara is not in good repair and there is a lot of air pollution.  Some of the area is still authentic but much has become too touristy.

541626276.name: Nice Place for a Stroll, Shopping and Dining.
541626276.author: a TripAdvisor user
541626276.reviewBody: This lake is very nice.  It has certainly come a long way since I first visited many years ago.  I went back a few years ago and they have added more.  The lake is a bit dry and you cannot go swimming.  This was a bit disappointing but if you\'re with good friends or family you can make the most of it.

540009233.name: very good environment but stil a lot of contamination.
540009233.author: a TripAdvisor user
540009233.reviewBody: the first impression you shall have arriving at Chapala is of course a very big lake. The problem is that because of the contamination you could not go into the lake to have a nice swim. they are divers small cities around the lake and also very fine restaurants at very reasonable prices. you could also make a tour by bot until the island. The all scenery is very fine from April tilll October when the all everything is nice green.

539162595.name: I was pleasantly surprised!
539162595.author: a TripAdvisor user
539162595.reviewBody: I remmeber years ago the lake was nothing special, but it has definitely changed! It\'s beautiful! It has great restaurants and many places to eat... The malec\u00f3n is very clean and pleasant, the people are friendly. I would recommend it for a nice, relaxed weekend visit..

534050591.name: Wonderful Slice of Life!
534050591.author: a TripAdvisor user
534050591.reviewBody: The lake is much more massive than I had ever expected. The malecon in Chapala is prettier than in Aijijic. Lots of pretty flowers, fountains and very friendly people. There are several restaurants to just sit and pass the time. One thing we noticed in this area as in all of the Guadalajara region no one rushes you to pay the check. You literally have to ask for it! You probably could stay all day lounging at a restaurant near the lake. As in all of Mexico the Mexican people are warm and hospitable but in Ajijic we tried to speak to many of the ex-pats since we were looking for homes to retire there but found the ex-pats to not be too friendly. All but one person said hello back to us as we walked the streets, most lowered their head and walked right past us. Sad but true. The ex-pats should be thrilled to live in such an awesome inexpensive area. I think we will look elsewhere to retire.

532496176.name: Quick Trip
532496176.author: a TripAdvisor user
532496176.reviewBody: My wife and I visited Lake Chapala a few months back while in Guadalajara.  We stayed in a very nice AirBnB and fully enjoyed Restoran del Mar and Historica Buenos Ayres

532162798.name: I hate making this review
532162798.author: a TripAdvisor user
532162798.reviewBody: I hesitate writing this because I have lived here for over 10 years in a village called Ajijic ..... I fell in love with the village , the people , and the weather .... it is truly a paradise a mile up in the heavens ...... the weather is spring like 90% of the time and the natives are friendly and most speak English and are tolerant of your attempts at Spanish ....... the sunsets are spectacular ........ watch it with your love over drinks and food at one of the great restaurants along the lake ....... I hesitate because I know as it\'s fame will be it\'s demise eventually ......sad but that\'s progress

532023273.name: Beautiful Lake
532023273.author: a TripAdvisor user
532023273.reviewBody: Definitely go see Chapala, and downtown Ajijic. It is spectacular and if yearning for a USA experience, go for burgers, fries and shakes at Trip\'s Burger right across the street from Walmart. Only an hour from GDL and beautiful quaint lakeside community.

530041134.name: Lake Chapala is a nice lake less than two hour drive from Guadalajara.
530041134.author: a TripAdvisor user
530041134.reviewBody: There are several little towns like Chapala and Ajijic and Jocotepc on the lake. Perhaps the most "famous" to tourists and ex-pats is Ajijic due to its large gringo population and many cute shops, restaurants and arty stuff in the streets and shops.

526870047.name: I ane lived her for 12 years
526870047.author: a TripAdvisor user
526870047.reviewBody: I have good friends in the states as well as  friends from around the world. They all LOVE visiting here, and many say they want to retire here. The weather is fantastic, the people, both Mexican and Expat, are remarkable, and the "vibe" is laid-back wonderful.

522332270.name: Restful Excursion and Great Shopping!
522332270.author: a TripAdvisor user
522332270.reviewBody: We visited Lake Chapala while in Guadalajara; it is less than an hour\'s drive. It was a very comfortable experience after being in Mexico for a week. The signs are in English and Spanish because of the large US expatriate population. With the strong dollar, you get a big bang for the buck on everything.

521947165.name: A Great Day\'s Outing in the Country
521947165.author: a TripAdvisor user
521947165.reviewBody: Travel less than an hour (traffic willing) outside Guadalajara and come upon enormous Lake Chapala and its many charming towns.  There\'s a small island that you can take a dinghy to for dining.  A visit to Ajijic is a must for its lovely cobblestone streets, public art, shopping and restaurants.  Chapala has waterside seafood restaurants such as Don Juan.  Many Expats live in the area.

520104468.name: Relaxing
520104468.author: a TripAdvisor user
520104468.reviewBody: Lake Chapala was a great place to go and relax. The food was good definitely take the boat ride to scorpion island and the tour.

519708142.name: Legendary Lake Chapala
519708142.author: a TripAdvisor user
519708142.reviewBody: Very nice drive from Guadalajara, very friendly town and great place to just take in mother nature! Great seafood restaurants and lovely church.

501024570.name: Not much to see
501024570.author: a TripAdvisor user
501024570.reviewBody: It was a long drive from Guadalajara. My advice is to skip it as there\'s not much to see there. We took a boat to Scorpion Island and then had our driver take us to Lake Ajijic. Nice scenery but we live in California and have Lake Tahoe. Just didn\'t think it was worth our time.

500402221.name: lovely views
500402221.author: a TripAdvisor user
500402221.reviewBody: I had a wonderful time in Chapala, I went on a day excursion from Guadalajara with my mother. We had a lovely time, it is definitely a place to see if your in Guadalajara.

487813171.name: Calm & beautiful
487813171.author: a TripAdvisor user
487813171.reviewBody: Our tour operator cancelled our trip and wanted to take us to another one instead, we said no, and took a taxi to the bus station, taxi heard us we were dissapointed with this cancellation...this was the only day we could do a day trip.. he offered to take us for $500 pesos...round trip for 3-4 hours... he even took us to Ajijic... this looks like a great retirement place! the weather is ideal!

486452932.name: Shop, Eat, Relax
486452932.author: a TripAdvisor user
486452932.reviewBody: At our arrival to the outskirts to the Chapala, it magnificent view of the lake dimensions may  be apreciated. The is a local crafts market located on the side of t)3 town bordering the water.  You may fing a good drink, a eye catching finger food or just a place to apreaciate the beauty of the area.  Visit don\'t have to be long. Is better if you get a tour guide to get you to this location as per there a many little ting that may be both visiting on the way.  Also if you drive west about 30 min, a good meal and a lake tour may be achived at @ Jocotepec.

477740058.name: I was surprised by Lake Chapala
477740058.author: a TripAdvisor user
477740058.reviewBody: My brother lives lakeside in Ajijic along with 30,000 more gringos.  I live in Oaxaca where there are probably less than 1,000 gringos so I was curious to see his home.  There are several cities around the lake but Ajijic is one of the best known.  The lake is beautiful but most residents advised against swimming in it.  Ajijic is a village of cobblestone streets and beautiful homes.  Ajijic boasts one of the largest English libraries in Mexico.  There are many activities but shopping and dining are most popular with tourists.  All the restaurants we visited had English menus and English speaking waiters.  Art galleries and boutique shops abound. The village is clean and quiet.  I especially recommend it if you are considering retirement in Mexico.

476180499.name: Lunch at the lake
476180499.author: a TripAdvisor user
476180499.reviewBody:
Chapala is the largest lake in Mexico around 200 kilometers long.

The lake itself is kind of dirty and there are not much of a wildlife going on.

Some tilapia sand catfish lives in the lake.

If you are near it's worth to eat at some of the nearby restaurants but I would not travel from far to visit.

474789330.name: Interesting, but not sure it\'s worth a day trip.
474789330.author: a TripAdvisor user
474789330.reviewBody: Large lake. Flea markets on the shores are interesting. I might be more interested walking around town and checking out the local life, but the lake itself wasn\'t really fantastic or anything.

472986554.name: Lake Chapala Tour
472986554.author: a TripAdvisor user
472986554.reviewBody: Lake Chapala is over an hour away drive from Guadalajara, and the lake\'s coast is full of small artistic shopping full of ceramic, paintings, etc. There are plenty of small restaurants serving tasty and inexpensive food. There are inexpensive boat rides availale to the "Isla de los Alacranes" island, which is a small site with some restaurants and plenty of history (ask for a local tour to understand the different archeological sites). On the lake coast you can experience the  "Voladores" show (every half hour) where four people rotate and slowly come down some ropes from an extremely high pole (this is a street show, and they only expect donations from their spectators). Beyond the lake area there are plenty of restaurants and shopping stores full of artistic choices (ceramic, clothing, glass, paintings, etc.).

470122647.name: 1st visit absolutely beautiful and natural
470122647.author: a TripAdvisor user
470122647.reviewBody: Relatives brought a group of about 10 last week to visit. About 40 min or so outside Guadalajara. Quiet little town, with shops. Churchs, and many vendors. Bought ice cream on lake shore and watched the "flyers" perform their pole dance as they hang upside down and slowly circle the pole as they come down. Artistic and beautiful to watch (don\'t forget to give some pesos.) We hired a boat and enjoyed a ride on the lake for about an hour. Highly recommend you do this. Negotiate with the boat owner directly for the best price. Peaceful and natural setting. Highly recommend.

469217514.name: Beautiful views!
469217514.author: a TripAdvisor user
469217514.reviewBody: Chapala is an absolute gem! Beautiful lake with plenty to see and do.  A walk alongside the lake is a must! Loved the mercado down the little town\'s "downtown" area.  My son even ate fried crickets there!

467827122.name: Great restaurant there
467827122.author: a TripAdvisor user
467827122.reviewBody: The Monte Coxala is a unique looking restaurant located in the Chapala area Raquette club. There\'s a guard at gate but just tell him you\'re going to restaurant. Truly delicious margaritas and authentic, of course, Mexican food.  Worth the drive out of Guadalajara, about 1 hour from centro.  The drive goes past all the berry farms.

464340181.name: Happy place with happy people.
464340181.author: a TripAdvisor user
464340181.reviewBody: Very popular vacation spot for both Mexicans and tourists.  Lovely scenery and lots of great restaurants.

460788668.name: Beautiful
460788668.author: a TripAdvisor user
460788668.reviewBody: This one of the largest, if not the largest, lakes in Mexico. The area surrounding it is beautiful. There are numerous restaurants located near the lake and many activities for family enjoyment.

457090406.name: Pleasant Day Trip
457090406.author: a TripAdvisor user
457090406.reviewBody: We took a day trip to Lake Chapala and  the surrounding area via a private car from Guadalajara.  As  you approach the  Lake the area is surrounded by gated communities and condo developments, as  you get closer there are roadside vendors. The. Lake is large and the banks have restaurants and places to walk and relax. We were near the town of Ajijc.  We were only there for a day and walked around the town. If you are a lake as opposed to beach person you might want to spend more time but I did not feel that   being there for a day trip was that worthwhile.

456063451.name: Amazing!
456063451.author: a TripAdvisor user
456063451.reviewBody: A must go & see!  We took pictures, dined, & enjoyed family company!  We went for a wedding & it was beautiful.  We are at a restaurant with a park for the young kids & they loved it.

453199131.name: clean and friendly people
453199131.author: a TripAdvisor user
453199131.reviewBody: II spent the whole day there, took a lots of pictures..very good food at the market curios a very good price the plaza was so nice and the church impressive.I will be back soon

450805807.name: Total Surprise!!
450805807.author: a TripAdvisor user
450805807.reviewBody: What a lovely surprise to come over the mountains and find Lake Chapala and Ajijic!!! A charming community with a fabulous malecon along the lake. Rides and tiendas, a beautiful walkway and many local restaurants with a local flavour. We will definitely return when we can stay longer. AND OH!!! The town was all dressed up for Christmas!!! Gorgeous!!!

447194714.name: Must see
447194714.author: a TripAdvisor user
447194714.reviewBody: Being the biggest lake in Mexico you must see? Weather the expat tourist area of ajijic or the old Spanish island prison of the coast of mezacal this lakes highly recommended. The tourism areas aren\'t the best with higher price stays. Chapala, jotepic,mezcal, octlan are the true gems of the lake.only because of culture and no over growth of houses that  don\'t fit it

445925416.name: Lake for old time\'s sake
445925416.author: a TripAdvisor user
445925416.reviewBody: This used to be chapala\'s lake, but now is just an empty space, filled with rotten fish and stinky water...

441992455.name: Lake Chapala!
441992455.author: a TripAdvisor user
441992455.reviewBody: Well I come here to just check place but I do not see special ! Like normal tourists town lot of shopping and restaurant !  Lake front is nice to walk nicety maintenance my friend is wheelchair he doesn\'t have any Problems!

441454195.name: Went early
441454195.author: a TripAdvisor user
441454195.reviewBody: I went early, small town,  with walkway with a lake. At the end of the tour they take you down, I guess is the restaurant area with the foreign presence? A getaway for the locals.

440999913.name: This is a really nice day trip
440999913.author: a TripAdvisor user
440999913.reviewBody: We booked a day tour with GDL Adventure. GDLadventure.mx   through our Hotel Morales.  Ask for the guide Paco; his english is excellent and he took good care of us.  Clean, new mini van w/ac. Lots of stops along the way, including a tequila tasting stop. Plan on an 8 hour day. Dinner overlooking the water, then a sunset cruise on the lake. Charming little town. Safe to walk around.

440621474.name: Very interesting place
440621474.author: a TripAdvisor user
440621474.reviewBody: Went with friends to visit other friends. Small quaint area. Went to farmers market very nice. Walked out he malecon very interesting.  Went to small village in the hills on the other side of the lake interesting drive.  On 40 minutes from Guadalajara.   Only thing here is traffic is really congested. Only one 2 lane road in and out.

439773332.name: The area is very picturesque and is the largest fresh water lake in Mexico.
439773332.author: a TripAdvisor user
439773332.reviewBody: Several towns around this very large lake share a lot of local beauty and the climate is a micro one controlled by the vast lake and surrounding mountains.

438166338.name: Lake Chapala/Ajijic is a must
438166338.author: a TripAdvisor user
438166338.reviewBody:
If you are spending a few days in Guadalajara, then Lake Chapala is a must. To see the largest lake in Mexico, you can choose from Chapala (more popular, less expensive) or Ajijic (more sophisticated and more expensive) or why not do both.

In Ajijic, you starting point should be the Plaza (center of town) there are plenty of Art Galleries of all shapes and sizes that will be worth your time, then walk down to the Malecon for a pleasant walk along the lake. Since there are plenty of nice BnB to spend the night (at many price points) do not hesitate to spend the night. One of the nicest one around is “Casas de las Flores” (not the cheapest, but great service). 

There are plenty of restaurants to choose from, at every price point, but for a great dining experience with good live music, “4” is your best bet (not cheap but worth every penny). If you are on a budget "Moya" is definitely the best quality street vendor (across the Pemex gas station) you'll find around. The cobblestone streets are uneven so make sure you have comfortable footwear.

BTW, No you don’t swim in that lake, and boat tours on the lake are hard to find. But if you want to spend the day relaxing, there are Thermal Waters in the next town to the west called San Juan Cosala and you might be able to find a private boat.

437439000.name: Ice cream of Chapala rocks !
437439000.author: a TripAdvisor user
437439000.reviewBody: I have visited Chapala lake several times. I must say is fun ! They have great ice cream and little dried fishes that you eat them as snacks with salt, lime and chile!

436133744.name: Anniversary trip
436133744.author: a TripAdvisor user
436133744.reviewBody: We really enjoy our walk in Lago de Chapala,  the weather was just perfect and the lake was beautiful lots of vendors in the board walk very clean  place, nice to sit on one of the many restaurants and enjoy a drink with the beautiful view.

435691592.name: Largest lake in Mexico
435691592.author: a TripAdvisor user
435691592.reviewBody: This is a must-see if you visit Guadalajara. The lake are has a very good weather year-round and offers lots of food and entertainment options. Chapala gives you a taste of old Mexico, while Ajijic has a vibrant ex-pat community. You can also find hot water springs on San Juan Cosal\u00e1 and take a day off in a spa. Lots to do and to see.

431968052.name: Good memories
431968052.author: a TripAdvisor user
431968052.reviewBody: We went back to Chapala lake after many years, there are many options for lunch or dinner around the lake but it was a little dirty, hopefully soon I can go back and take a boat ride with my family.

431573395.name: Visit to the largest lake in Mexico
431573395.author: a TripAdvisor user
431573395.reviewBody: Worth the trip to the lake and to the island where prisoners were held and the history as told by our guide

427401508.name: Ajijic trip report
427401508.author: a TripAdvisor user
427401508.reviewBody:
My wife and I are a bit over 60 and residents of Southern CA.  We recently spent a week of vacation just outside of Ajijic on the north shore of Laguna Chapala.
We flew into Guadalajara from Tijuana - there is now a very good entry bridge taking you directly into the TJ airport from the US side of the border.  The plane fare from there was about half of the cost from San Diego.  The airport is nice and the flight was great.
Arriving in Guadalajara, we were met by a driver from the agency we rented our car from.  We used a service based in Ajijic which can be found via web search.  The driver took us to Ajijic where we took over the car, proceeded to the local Walmart (in the center of Ajijic) for provisions, and then on to our casita rental out of town.
During our week stay, we spent two days visiting Guadalajara, one day touring the town of Tequila, and another driving to a mountain town above the south side of the lake.
All of our activities were enjoyable and we drove to all except a tour of the historical center of Guadalajara.  Driving was fairly tame by international standards and we didn't have any problems.  The quality of the roads varies from outstanding to abysmal.  In rural areas, the frequent use of speed bumps requires constant vigilance to prevent vehicle damage.
My wife is always concerned that travel in Mexico is dangerous.  Even she agrees, however, that we never felt even a hint of any danger during the entirety of our trip.  Yes, we did see heavily armed federales/military from time to time, but never any of the bad guys they must be protecting against.  On the contrary, our experiences with the locals were very pleasant throughout (I do speak fair Spanish).
The most pleasant surprise was the strength of the dollar.  The peso was valued at just about 5 cents during our visit.  This meant that most everything we bought was very inexpensive compared to US standards.  Especially on food and drink (our primary expenditures) the prices were great.  At the best restaurants in town, we we able to have a 3 course meal with wine for around $40 for the two of us.  Meals we would expect to cost $100+ at home.  And for the most part, the food was excellent.  Our only complaint was that most of the menu options were steak or seafood that we could get at home.  There were surprisingly few offerings of what I would call traditional Mexican cuisine.  
This may be due to the fact that Ajijic is the hub of American/Canadian expatriate housing in this part of Mexico.  Apparently some 30,000 expats make their homes in the area.  We met a fair number and all reported loving the area and having no intention of returning to the US or Canada (including the American owner in the house above our casita).
Tips for visiting the area are to do some good research in advance.  We stayed around 20 minutes out of town (Ajijic) in a lovely and inexpensive casita with a beautiful view of the lake (through Airbnb).  Were we to go again, I would probably stay in town for the convenience of walking to stores and restaurants.  If you drive (and probably even if you don't), travel with some form of GPS map.  Navigating Guadalajara would have been very hard without a cell phone map and getting around in rural areas needs guidance as well.  I would also try to see if you can get a map which shows exactly where desired restaurants, stores, etc. are located.  In many small Mexican towns, the streets within the towns are very narrow, made of cobblestones and have limited parking.  There were a couple restaurants we wanted to try but didn't because we had no idea how find them.  Unfortunately, few of the places we wanted to patronize could be found on Google maps or through a Google search.
Ajijic is not a place for nightlife.  Most of the restaurants close by 9:00 on weekdays and when we were there (October) everything was very quiet except for Saturday and Sunday nights when the Mexicans were out and about with families.
Will we go again?  Maybe.  I love travelling in Mexico, but there are many other places in the world (and Latin America) that we want to visit.  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend a visit to the area. 
I almost forgot to mention the weather.  We decided it's very close to perfect.  A touch warm in the day if you are in the sun, a touch cool in the evening if there is a moderate breeze, but mostly just right Goldilocks!
Two thumbs up for Mexico, Mexicans, and the greater Guadalajara area.  Yo big D, take your beautiful wall and put it where the sun don't shine!
Enjoy your travels wherever they take you!

424872571.name: Perfect place to spend a evening with friends
424872571.author: a TripAdvisor user
424872571.reviewBody: Had a good time good food good ice cream we also enjoyed a boat ride to alacran island, plan to come back next year can\'t wait

422562294.name: Nice and Relax
422562294.author: a TripAdvisor user
422562294.reviewBody: All the attractions are relaxing to the point you will not want to leave this place!\nLake Chapala is a beautiful nature gift, you can go over in a boat, there is a dock where you can rent this tour and have a great time with your friends.\nThe breeze is something you will enjoy, careful because you can get dizzy, if you are not good in water tours, you better stay in ground. The local market offers all kind of food, snacks and beverages, and also really nice souvenirs, something you can buy is keychains with all kind of figures, people are very kind and willing to help you!, there are places to have dinner and hang around such a beautiful view!

421237069.name: A Few Historical Sites in Ajijic and Chapala
421237069.author: a TripAdvisor user
421237069.reviewBody:
Here are a few historical sites I visited recently in Ajijic and Chapala. You may want to check them out when you're in the area.

THE OLD CRUSHING MILL
There was once an operating gold mine in the hills just above Ajijic. While the old mine itself is too dangerous to enter, you can visit the ruins of the crushing mill (see location below). This is on private property, but there's no fence, and a family living on the premises unhesitatingly gave us permission to wander both inside and outside the decrepit buildings. Outside there's a long, sturdy earthen ramp where ore-laden wagons were pulled up to the crusher. It would be very interesting to visit this place with someone knowledgeable about mining.

LA CASA DE LA RUSA
This was the home of a mysterious horsewoman who rode around dressed all in black while being swindled out of the proceeds of the gold mine mentioned above. The house is located at 26 Independencia, where the number plaque shows the silhouette of the legendary Horsewoman in Black. Her name was Ayenara Zara Alexeyewa, a Russian ballerina, and according to Judy King's blog she and her dance partner/foster brother bought the above-mentioned gold mine in the 1920s “hoping to fulfill their dreams to produce and present great Russian ballets here in Mexico.” Jim and Carole Cook say the mine was called La Misericordia and La Rusa was being swindled by her Mexican partners until mine manager Quilocho Retolaza came to her rescue. Quilocho had been one of Pancho Villa's most dashing officers and La Rusa herself (under the pen name Frances De Brundige) tells the story of how he saved her from swindlers and bandits in the book "Quilocho and the Dancing Stars," available (used) from Amazon.com. There are lots of old photos and memorabilia about Zara Alexeyewa in La Nueva Posada's Restaurante La Rusa.

LA VIEJA POSADA
This famous old restaurant was built in the 1500s and has had many reincarnations. Today it is called Restaurante María Isabel. Here, says Jorge Varela, is where D. H. Lawrence (and later many other famous artists) used to stop by for a Tequila and Sangrita. The correct procedure for imbibing these two drinks, said our companions, is not to mix them together, but to sip first one and then the other. Now for this ceremony, the tequila must be blanco while the sangrita is red. When I asked what was in the sangrita, I immediately learned what's not in it: alcohol. After that, I got a different version of the ingredients from each of my friends and every source I checked. I guess that means you'll always be surprised when you drink it!

D.H. LAWRENCE'S ROOM
This is in the town of Chapala, at number 307 Zaragoza Street, and is now known as Quinta Quetzalcoatl Boutique Hotel B&B. “This is where Lawrence stayed while he lived in Chapala,” said the owner, Rob Cracknell, an Australian painter, who kindly showed us all around. Well, QQ, as they call it in Chapala, turned out to be one of the most gorgeous places to stay I had ever seen, with beautiful trees, fountains, grottos, flowers and cacti. In the middle of the patio was a charming pool with a serpent motif, shaped with secluded nooks and a jacuzzi. Lawrence's room was just as attractive. On the wall was a picture of the writer and his wife Frieda, along with the text of the telegram Lawrence sent her in 1923: “Chapala Paradise. Take evening train.” The train is long gone, but “Chapala Paradise” still says it all.

How to get there:
In Ajijic: The Crushing mill (N20 17.892 W103 16.303) is at the south end of Flores Magón.  La Casa de la Rusa is at 26 Independencia (N20 17.877 W103 15.887), between Aquiles Serdán and 5 de Mayo. La Vieja Posada, now called Restaurante María Isabel, is located at the south end of Morelos street at N20 17.828 W103 15.756.

In Chapala:  Quinta Quetzalcoatl is number 307 near the south end of Zaragoza Street, just south of Niños Heroes (N20 17.299 W103 11.467).

420586400.name: Beautiful
420586400.author: a TripAdvisor user
420586400.reviewBody: Lake Chapala is a very beautiful place approximately 45 minute drive from Guadalajara.  We met several ex-pats who live there and enjoyed talking with them about life there.  They all love it and it seems to be a thriving community.

418269243.name: Mexico\'s largest lake.
418269243.author: a TripAdvisor user
418269243.reviewBody: You can spend a full day visiting this lake, they are many good restaurants, hot springs in San Juan Cosala, also it is possible to take a boat in Mezcala and go to "Presidio Island".

418043162.name: * Visitando Chapala - Visiting Chapala *
418043162.author: a TripAdvisor user
418043162.reviewBody: Simply Beautiful and inviting place to visit. Friendly city full of Mexican traditions, with a nice display of hospitality from their people.

414063512.name: Relax!!
414063512.author: a TripAdvisor user
414063512.reviewBody: Romantic,  best place to romance , food is very good , all is cheap , this place is magic , all the town \u2764\ufe0f

414046569.name: Nice Scenic Day Out
414046569.author: a TripAdvisor user
414046569.reviewBody: I got the bus from the Antigua Central Camionera in Guadalajara. It cost 50 cents to get into the station and then $50 MXN for the direct, 1 hour bus trip to the town of Chapala. Buses run very regularly from early in the morning til 10:00pm. When you get into Chapala, go through the station, out the main door and turn left. You then just walk straight down through the pretty main st. and you\'ll arrive at the lake. \n\nIt\'s very scenic and the little pier and Malecon (promenade) are very nice to walk along, although neither are very big. Unless you leave the town, you won\'t be able to walk around much of the lake. There are also boats that will take you out onto the lake from the pier area. It\'s definitely worth going out for a look and there seemed to be plenty of decent places to eat. I can recommend the Cafe Paris on the main street for good coffee and snacks.

412492745.name: A good alternative travel option
412492745.author: a TripAdvisor user
412492745.reviewBody: Though the promenade and boardwalk is clean and pretty with good views of the city and lake, the lake itself is not kept clean. Once you are on the boat heading to one of the islands it gives a great feeling - rustic but good.

409405318.name: Bus trip to Chapala
409405318.author: a TripAdvisor user
409405318.reviewBody: Chapala has made a lot of improvements since our last visit about five years ago, their malecon is very clean and green with trees and bushes all tru the streach of the Malecon. We had lunch at one of the many restaurants along the cost of the lake. For $250.00 pesos you can take a boat ride along the lake in one of the many lanchas . Also there are a lot of vendors that sell food and ice cream and souvenirs. It a nice place to spend at least half a day. We took a bus from the bus station about ten minutes from downtown Guadalajara, It will cost you about $50.00 pesos and will take approx.one hour direct without any stops.

407299024.name: Ex-pats galore
407299024.author: a TripAdvisor user
407299024.reviewBody: Beautiful area outside the main city of Guadalajara.  Many ex-pats (Americans) live here. Peaceful and scenic place to visit.

404474596.name: Romantic? Hummmm, maybe.  Nostalgic, certainly
404474596.author: a TripAdvisor user
