191850082.reviewBody: The building is still in use today.  Orozco\'s paintings in the stairwell and in the Congress are worth seeing, as his work is so full of passion.  I loved the architecture of the building and the magnificent doors.

187291880.name: My favorite Orozco
187291880.author: a TripAdvisor user
187291880.reviewBody: I\'ve visited the palace twice, now, two years apart.  The second time I saw the Orozco mural of Father Hidalgo was as stunning as the first time, even though I thought I had it etched in my mind. Looking up the stairwell at Hidalgo is absolutely breath-taking.  If you only have time to see one thing on your trip to Guadalajara, make sure it\'s this mural!

180650791.name: historic building
180650791.author: a TripAdvisor user
180650791.reviewBody: Very well mantained with a museum that lets you get to know Guadalajara\'s history.  The entrance is free.

175493953.name: Beautiful palace
175493953.author: a TripAdvisor user
175493953.reviewBody: Beautiful archetecture and ecorative inside of the palace of the governor covered with beautiful murals on the walls. Though the building is surrounded with police with machine guns, it felt safe to tour.

174022255.name: Nice tour
174022255.author: a TripAdvisor user
174022255.reviewBody:
Very nice tour through its rooms. It tells the history of Jalisco and Hidalgo.

Mural from Orozco is impressive and very imponent. It is possible to see some of the scketches and pre-painting.

Really good time.

169649052.name: If in dowtown
169649052.author: a TripAdvisor user
169649052.reviewBody: An interesting historical public building in the heart of the city.   Take a glance, it won\'t hurt. The entrance is free and potos are permitted.

158866807.name: Very nice view
158866807.author: a TripAdvisor user
158866807.reviewBody: Great place to visit from outside... remeber the ancient buildings... it is on downtown . . . You can walk over there and find also another nice places..

155618141.name: Orozco murals rate a WOW !!
155618141.author: a TripAdvisor user
155618141.reviewBody: The mural of Miguel Hidalgo in the staircase of the Government building is truly spectacular.  Not only is it gigantic but it captures the full ferocity of the start of the Mexican revolution in 1810.  Make sure that you also go up one more level to the old Congress chamber and see the totally different second set of murals. Take time to wander through the 18th century building itself and see how they have renovated it to modern usage.

154123679.name: Historical place; nicely maintained
154123679.author: a TripAdvisor user
154123679.reviewBody: Nice to be able to move about freely in a Govt (State) institution. Great mural of Hidalgo fighting oppression and slavery on the ceiling when going up the stairs. Well preserved building.

153687564.name: Niecely preserved government building
153687564.author: a TripAdvisor user
153687564.reviewBody: I actually was directed there to find an exhibit on tequila, which I didn\'t find but the murals alone were worth the visit.  It was actually quite calm on a Sunday afternoon with just a few visitors.

153403869.name: The murals!
153403869.author: a TripAdvisor user
153403869.reviewBody: This is a lovely (and cool) classically colonial building of stone with a courtyard in the middle. The main attraction for us was the dramatic and historical murals both in the stairway and in the meeting room for the congress. Worth a stop.

150449235.name: It was a friendly pace to buy all sorts of tipico Mixico. I felt safe. There was so many handi craft things there made w
150449235.author: a TripAdvisor user
150449235.reviewBody: What can I say negative but if you dont speack the language or know english even this palce acn be confusing. Translations of English German and Chinese

149793627.name: VERY BEAUTIFUL
149793627.author: a TripAdvisor user
149793627.reviewBody: Surrounded by tons of polica with guns ! Get used to it in Mexico ! They are not overly friendly but they have a job to do You ll often find peaceful protests here too Dont worry about them. Take the time to read a lot of the information posted inside its a beautiful old building !

149103829.name: Nice murals by Orozco !!
149103829.author: a TripAdvisor user
149103829.reviewBody: This place is free to just walk inside and take pictures. The paintings by muralist Orozco are well worth photographing. Some of the inner courtyards have orange trees like those I\'ve seen in Seville, Spain. You can even walk into the congressional debating hall-complete with more murals!!!

142088234.name: It\'s Free, You Have to Go!
142088234.author: a TripAdvisor user
142088234.reviewBody: What a wonderful gem of a place to keep open to the people and tourist, there\'s two beautiful murals by Orozco, a museum and your free to walk about the palace.

139703677.name: See this.
139703677.author: a TripAdvisor user
139703677.reviewBody: There are two levels, murals, and various exhibitions of different types.  For example, on my visit there was an exhibition of fabrics, clothing, natural dyes, an exhibition of agave and tequila, and an exhibition of paintings.

133883766.name: Government.... Enough said!
133883766.author: a TripAdvisor user
133883766.reviewBody: We only saw the outside of the building wich dates back to the 1800\'s. It\'s old and it\'s nice for picture taking other than that not much.....\n

133335583.name: Excellent murals!
133335583.author: a TripAdvisor user
133335583.reviewBody: This building has one of most impressing murals ever!

132102935.name: Governor\'s Palace, a big disappointment
132102935.author: a TripAdvisor user
132102935.reviewBody: Everyone told us to be sure to take in the Governor\'s Palace to get a feel for what Guadalajara is all about.  You can\'t miss it if you hit the center historical area.  Eventhough the building is from the late 1500\'s and is in pretty good condition you have to assume living in that time frame was no great shakes.  The building has very little of anything in it either in furniture or artifacts.  Most rooms have maybe one piece of ancient furniture and a case with either artifacts or nothing at all.  The whole building is quite sparse of anything.  Not much of a museum.  The Hidalgo fresco is Ok but certainly not a Mona Lisa or Cistine Chapel.  If time is limited I would say don\'t waste your time with this one.

129124706.name: Excellent guide
129124706.author: a TripAdvisor user
129124706.reviewBody: Took this tour with OfficialTours.otlc@gmail.com in April from Lake Chapala area. It was a little warm but the Official Tours of Lake Chapala guide knew how to keep things cool, interesting and fun!

127688627.name: One of the many sites in the historic center
127688627.author: a TripAdvisor user
127688627.reviewBody: I think there is a small charge to enter.  Lots of exhibits on early Mexico history.  Worth a couple hour visit while staying near the main square.

127414965.name: Fresco\'s of Hidalgo in the Palacio de Gobierno
127414965.author: a TripAdvisor user
127414965.reviewBody: Great frescos!  There are two main frescoes- on the stairway walking up to the second floor and in the Congress room.  They are huge!!!! The building itself is beautiful, outide and in.  It also contains a small museum of Mexican history that you should see.

124570929.name: Beautiful building and murals
124570929.author: a TripAdvisor user
124570929.reviewBody: We stopped in to see the murals here since we didn\'t have time to go to the Hospicio. The building itself is very pretty and the murals are amazing. There is also a museum, and part of the building is currently being renovated.\nAs a plus, there are clean bathrooms available free of charge!

124129927.name: Near the cathedral
124129927.author: a TripAdvisor user
124129927.reviewBody: Here is the huge Orozco mural going up the staircase that is nothing less than majestic. A must  see.

123416742.name: This is where the Hidalgo painting is
123416742.author: a TripAdvisor user
123416742.reviewBody: When you visit the Hospicio de Cabanas for the Orozco mural, don\'t look for the most famous one because it is here in the Palacio de Gobierno. Besides this painting there is not much else to see so it is a quick - free - visit so don\'t miss it!

123266158.name: Governor\'s Palace
123266158.author: a TripAdvisor user
123266158.reviewBody: The murals inside are well worth seeing and worth a visit.

123222147.name: Government Palace is a must see here.
123222147.author: a TripAdvisor user
123222147.reviewBody: An artist named Jose Clemente Orozco painted a giant hildago style painting here all over the grand arching ceiling, another can be found in the congress hall.\n\n It was painted in 1937, before the war, and is very insightful. Pick up a full colour pamphlet and read it, very cool stuff. The Palace its self is baroque ornamented, you won\'t regret seeing it, very colonial completed in 1790.

123076645.name: Hidalgo mural amazing!
123076645.author: a TripAdvisor user
123076645.reviewBody: The Miguel Hidalgo mural on the ceiling is a must when walking the histroic Guadalajara downtown area.

122235863.name: architecture...
122235863.author: a TripAdvisor user
122235863.reviewBody: just beautiful old-world charm.  plaza very distinctive.  lots happening.

122123742.name: Excellent site!
122123742.author: a TripAdvisor user
122123742.reviewBody: Totally renovated, the Goverment Palace it\'s not just and architectural place to visit, but a good museum about the city\'s history, and very enjoyable for all ages.

121495804.name: Beautiful
121495804.author: a TripAdvisor user
121495804.reviewBody: Historical Guadalajara at its best - gives the opportunity to feel old Guadalajara with the feel of a busy city because of location.

120436324.name: Amazing place with Orosco murals
120436324.author: a TripAdvisor user
120436324.reviewBody: This is a must-see attraction.  Be sure to engage one of the guides on the plaza as he will explain the history of murals and their meaning.

120201864.name: Orozco Mural worth the visit
120201864.author: a TripAdvisor user
120201864.reviewBody: This is right next to the Cathedral and worth a visit for the Orozco mural.

90743664.name: More Orozco magic!
90743664.author: a TripAdvisor user
90743664.reviewBody: We visited the Palacio de Gobierno after viewing the Orozco murals at the Hospicio Cabanas. Entrance is free to this attraction.  Although there are guards at the front of the building, they won\'t discourage you from entering and you can walk right past. The giant mural of Mexican Revolutionary priest Miguel Hidalgo just up the stairs on your right, is not to be missed.  Be sure to take the time to view and appreciate the mural from all sides, as perspective is a key element in this, and other Orozco paintings. There is a second large mural up the stairs within a separate room. Be sure to look for it. We encountered an unusual tour guide sitting on the steps by the name of Xiao Lin, who offered a colourful and amusing perspective of the murals. He speaks 8 languages (!) and is more than happy to give short tours to tourists for a few pesos.

17974392.name: Art and architecture not to be missed!
17974392.author: a TripAdvisor user
17974392.reviewBody: This building was a great place to visit. In the heart of town, the Palacio de Gobierno is a beautiful structure, featuring breathtaking murals by Jose Orozco (worth the trip to the building on their own). There\'s other pieces of Mexican history to be seen here as well. Another positive for this place is clean bathrooms on the first floor near the rear of the building. There is also a tourist information center just inside the entrance. Make this a stop on your tour!

16152458.name: Highlight of the city
16152458.author: a TripAdvisor user
16152458.reviewBody: I just have to jump in here and mention that these murals are world class. They are not simply a neat experience.....they are an unforgetable experience.  My friend and I thought they were the best highlight of the city.

12056919.name: Awesome murals - great first stop in Guadalajara
12056919.author: a TripAdvisor user
12056919.reviewBody: A great first place to visit on a walk around the historical downtown district. There\'s a tourist information booth just inside the doorway on the right - pick up a map and some advice - then go into the beautiful courtyard and head up the stairs to the right. The Orozco mural is mindboggling  - even if you don\'t like the artist\'s style, be amazed at the scale and how difficult it must have been to paint on the high curved ceilings.\n\nOn the upper level head into the door marked "Congreso" to see where the Jalisco congress sits. Again, amazing Orozco murals to be seen. A local told us (after we\'d visited) that there are some strange visual effects if one looks at the mural whilst walking through the curved chamber.

621423950.name: Good place to work out
621423950.author: a TripAdvisor user
621423950.reviewBody: Ride a bike, walk, run and if you get early catch one of the many classes in different spots of the park. Good place for a get together with the family and share pizzas or make a barbecue. No alcohol is allowed.

618733283.name: Great park for sports and families
618733283.author: a TripAdvisor user
618733283.reviewBody: Running track of 6k length one loop, different surfaces from sandy to trail like, gravel and road, a 50m lane aquatic centre at one end, the option to hire trampolines for the kids as well as playgrounds, and there are tennis courts and go cart hires as well.

606107697.name: A beautiful open space to go with family, friends and even with your dogs!
606107697.author: a TripAdvisor user
606107697.reviewBody: You can take your bicycles to the park or rent them there. It\'s also good for walking or jogging. Many families use to have a picnic in the park. Next to the park, there is a special place to train or walk your dogs. There are cafeterias to have a snack. Don\'t forget your water, sunscreen lotion and hats!

565170735.name: Morning walk to the park
565170735.author: a TripAdvisor user
565170735.reviewBody: We walked from our hotel, through the neighborhoods to this park.  It took almost 2 hours for the walk; about 5 miles.  The park is large and there are measured distance walking/running routes.  A small lake with ducks and other birds is at the north end.  There are some interesting trees.  They have a few snack stands there too.

563260778.name: One of the main green lungs of Guadalajara, conveniently placed
563260778.author: a TripAdvisor user
563260778.reviewBody:
Guadalajara seems to be a very active city, and the Parque Metropolitano sure shows this. It reflects on a city worried about not just having a "park" for the sake of it, but to incentive its population to use it. 

We went on a Monday morning and it had its fair share of amateur athletes: Yoga practitioners, runners, bicycle riders, cross-fitness practitioners and some people just chilling around. We were told that during weekends it gets crowded, because since it is a free park, many families use it for a picnic. 

A piece of the park was given to build the Zapopan Aquatic Center used in the Juegos Panamericanos of 2011 (named as the most modern aquatic center of Latin America and the second of the world), but it was not that big of a loss. It is well maintained.

If you like outdoor activities, it might be worth a visit. If you'd like to exercise while in Zapopan, this is a great spot! Mind that it closes at sunset... well, the park guards tell you to leave (since, being a large and not artificially illuminated area, it can be dangerous), but technically it can't be closed since it does not have gates.

548651155.name: The best park in town
548651155.author: a TripAdvisor user
548651155.reviewBody: A safe place to be with your family. Lots of green and there are a couple of small spots to grab a bite. You can rent bicycles, they have amenities for kids, etc. You can exercise as well. Congrats Guadalajara, don\u00b4t let it go.

542999052.name: Good for running
542999052.author: a TripAdvisor user
542999052.reviewBody: I entered the park through the entrance with the red towers, which is immediately in front of the "start/finish" line for the running paths. There are a couple of different paths that you can follow and there were a lot of small hills during my run. The paths weren\'t clearly labeled so I wasn\'t always sure which path I was on, but my trip around the park was 5 kilometers. If you aren\'t a runner, there were a lot of other activities that you could do in the park. You can rent bikes, there were yoga and boot camp classes going on while I was there, and there was a dog park. It is a nice place to go for some time outdoors.

539469303.name: Good for running or a picnic
539469303.author: a TripAdvisor user
539469303.reviewBody: I am impressed how the municipality has continuously given it maintenance every year it looks nicer. Every time I visit GDL I def go for a run at least a couple of times. The trees grow bigger and the grass greener. Now they\'ve opened the back side of the park it looks even nicer. with decent trails, snack bars, and public bathrooms also with amenities it makes it a good spot to go alone, with friends or with your family. You\'ll find grills for BBQs, movie under the stars once a week, trampolines, bike rentals, dog park and much more.

532132291.name: Parque Metropolitano
532132291.author: a TripAdvisor user
532132291.reviewBody: Parque Metropolitano is a great place to take the kids, to run, to walk, to have a picnic, or  to hold events.

459495722.name: A big city park
459495722.author: a TripAdvisor user
459495722.reviewBody: I ran a 5k in this park on Earth Day weekend. It a great place to exercise or enjoy a day with the family

437633960.name: It was sunny then rainy
437633960.author: a TripAdvisor user
437633960.reviewBody: It was so much fun walk around, drink a cold soda, smell the fresh air and lay in the grass just to enjoy nature & fresh aire.

436444724.name: Great Place to be at with anyone!
436444724.author: a TripAdvisor user
436444724.reviewBody: One of the few but great open spaces to be with Family, friends and couple.\nYou can have a picnic, carne asada (barbecue), pet walk, day with family, ride a bike....so many options.

434072026.name: Very nice place for a cool evening
434072026.author: a TripAdvisor user
434072026.reviewBody: This place is a large public park. It is pet-friendly and great for afternoon strolls and picnics. On the evenings they play movies on outside projectors. You can also rent bikes and trikes. Recommended.

427115646.name: Nice park to run and exercise
427115646.author: a TripAdvisor user
427115646.reviewBody: This is one of the nicest spots in Guadalajara to exercise. It\'s a very open space that let you get in there from any side. It\'s a safe place too. They could improve into gardening and spaces to just enjoy nature. If you are planning to run there are nice paths to make it happen.

402248730.name: Nice place for jogging
402248730.author: a TripAdvisor user
402248730.reviewBody: If you look for a place to go jogging, this park could be the one. Nice tracks, clean parks and dogs on leashes. You will find enough parking places around the park and also a few kiosks to buy water or energy drinks.\nI like this place very much and when we were living in Guadalajara I came regularly.

400130960.name: Great place for everyone
400130960.author: a TripAdvisor user
400130960.reviewBody: I really like this park because you could find attractions for every member of your party: walking, jogging, ciclying, renting bicycles for 2, 3 even 5 persons, jumping spots for kids. Al ot of green areas for having a pic nic, is just such a relaxing place in the middle of the city.

361209420.name: A Mini Central Park Near a Nice Shopping Mall
361209420.author: a TripAdvisor user
361209420.reviewBody: Not exactly a Central Park as in NYC, as this park is on the outskirts of the city, just beyond a Walmarts and the Galerias shopping mall, not far from the Bosque Primavera.  Still, a nice place to get some exercise and to stretch ones legs and lungs.

344749508.name: Fun on Sundays
344749508.author: a TripAdvisor user
344749508.reviewBody: I get out on my bike on Sundays when they close some of the roads for bikes and skateboarders, runners, walkers, anything but motorized vehicles, i follow the crowd past the ninos heros statue and about 8 miles later i am at the park. its big and beautiful there are pedal cars to rent and bikes to rent and all kinds of food but the best thing is the families, with all generations .. pets .. its just good to see so many people together and getting along

333522577.name: Spectacular (Huge) Park right in the City (Zapopan)
333522577.author: a TripAdvisor user
333522577.reviewBody:
This is one of those parks of which it is difficult to imagine the size -- it's huge!  There are all sorts of things to do, and additionally there are numerous activities being held here.

You will find it is filled with many happy residents of Zapopan out to enjoy the outdoors and have family events on most any weekend, and it's moderately busy during the week as well.

Really, the park is much more for residents than it is for tourists.  If you're in the area and there happens to be some event going on it would be great to go by and see.  But if you are in the heart of Guadalajara for only a brief visit I am not sure I would recommend making the trip just to see the park.

327679589.name: Fresh mind clear
327679589.author: a TripAdvisor user
327679589.reviewBody: nice park, very big, impossible to cover in one day, they have dog training programs, you can rent a bike, or take your own, have a snack or take a picnic. they have a paintball center, nothig other than grass and mentioned above to see. no access fee, free parking

301616073.name: Huge and good for sports
301616073.author: a TripAdvisor user
301616073.reviewBody:
Don't go here expecting a romantic or idyllic stroll through the park (better go to Colomos park for that). It is very functional if you are looking for exercise, though. You can go for a run without having to do laps, due to the size of the park). No entry fee.

You can rent a bike, use the exercise machines to work out, have a BBQ in one of the dedicated BBQ sites (just bring your own bricks and food), etc. The park has paved bike lanes. There is also entertainment for children (trampolines, playgrounds, activities on weekends, etc). You can buy food and fresh juices at the two main entrances.

Dogs are welcome too. There is a dog spa on Saturday's (next to the entrance with the red pillars).

298576572.name: Lots to do in this big open park
298576572.author: a TripAdvisor user
298576572.reviewBody: A great place to go for all the family. This is a clean and open park that provides activities and also the provision of food if required. Clearly this is used by the locals who appear to be at the more wealth end of the spectrum due to the location of the park in a wealth area. You can hire bikes, go karts and there are many play areas. There are places to eat, or have your own food as we as have a BBQ. There is a nearby commercial centre that you can visit afterwards, which is full of normal chains as well as a large Liverpool and Walmart. If you are in the area I would recommend a few hours in the park.

296032640.name: love this place
296032640.author: a TripAdvisor user
296032640.reviewBody: love visiting this place! they often have pet adoptions and movie (drive in style). Its great for running or lounging and its perfect that they welcome pets.

271010331.name: If you have a Dog this is your place
271010331.author: a TripAdvisor user
271010331.reviewBody: I really love to take my dog to this park it has an artificial Lake and a lot of games for train your dog. Very nice place.

266190830.name: Great Park
266190830.author: a TripAdvisor user
266190830.reviewBody: This park is huge and offers various things to spend the afternoon. I used to go running here and do some exercise. It offers some tracks for running, bars and other equipment, fields to play soccer, dog areas and picknick tables.

265369034.name: Great place to spend the day with family, friends and your dogs ! Excellent for dogs !
265369034.author: a TripAdvisor user
265369034.reviewBody: This park is great for dogs and to spend time with your loved ones, family and even friends.  The park is huge.  There is something for everything and there are even bike rentals.  I did not give it the 5 stars because I never saw water fountains for dogs, so if you are visiting with your dog, don\'t forget to bring a bottle of water for them or you can just buy them one there also.  You can bring food and put up a picnic under the trees, there is plenty of space, so you will hardly never have anyone besides you. There are playgrounds for children.  When it is sunny, it IS sunny so bring your sunblock if you are planning on staying under the sun for a long time or just wear a hat.  Overall, great place, relaxing and fun.

248815724.name: Huge!
248815724.author: a TripAdvisor user
248815724.reviewBody: This seemingly endless park is worth a visit. Normally it is filled with people out for a walk or jog. But if you leave the paths you can find a quite spot for a picnic. Don\'t leave anything valuable in your car - it is a popular spot for the smash and grab since exercisers often leave things in their cars.

204363610.name: nice park to spend the afternoon
204363610.author: a TripAdvisor user
204363610.reviewBody: the metropolitan park is a nice place to spend the afternoon with family, couple or friends.\na very popular place to exercise, to play soccer, lots of games for children.

152131367.name: A restful place in the city
152131367.author: a TripAdvisor user
152131367.reviewBody: We live near the park.  It has a tennis complex and a swimming complex that were built for the Pan Am games.  The park is quite large and has winding trails.  It has exercise equipment and shelters as well as refreshment stands.  The only thing that it needs is more parking.  It gets quite busy on the weekends but during the week it is a nice quiet place to go for a walk or bike ride.

136331503.name: One of the biggest parks in the city.
136331503.author: a TripAdvisor user
136331503.reviewBody: If you want to enjoy a moment outdoor this is the right place. \nA place to jogging, walking your dog, or just laying in the grass to read a book.

126656062.name: Park
126656062.author: a TripAdvisor user
126656062.reviewBody: Nice place to ride bikes, have a picnic.  Sundays and holidays are extremely busy.  Not much shade so might want to reconsider going on very sunny days...

125777938.name: Have a Jog.
125777938.author: a TripAdvisor user
125777938.reviewBody: Go run there. Don\'t expect more. The grass is yellow when it is not raining and there are not many trees so bring your sunblock lotion to avoid a terrible sunburn.\nThis place could be great with a little attention and maintenance.

123269195.name: Parque Metropolitano
123269195.author: a TripAdvisor user
123269195.reviewBody: Great recreational area on outskirts of town but in popular area off main roads.\n

654391852.name: Barranca de Huentitan Hike - Feb 2019
654391852.author: a TripAdvisor user
654391852.reviewBody:
My 23 year old daughter and I did this hike down and then back up the tracks in Nov 18' 
We came off the tracks about 2/3 of the way up, since she had twisted her ankle. The last 1/3 part of the tracks is the most difficult and with it being so steep, it's almost like rock climbing, given that you have to hold on to the rail as you climb. 
I am currently in Guadalajara (Feb 19') on vacation and my first attempt began at 6:30pm, to avoid the dreadful sun, which will quickly zap your strength. I only made it down to the part where we had not finished and then climbed back up the steepest part of the tracks, before it got dark. Although many people hike in the dark, it was hard to see the good hand/foot holds on the track, so I have not started in the evening again. Although the sun is no longer setting on the trails, the temperature, late afternoon was in the mid 80's, so not a good trade off. 
The last five days, I started at 6:30am and even though it is 50 degrees, I knew the sun would shine on me, most of the trail down and the all of the tracks up. Even though I slightly twisted my knee and ankle, my second day, I used a knee brace and taped up the ankle. I brought some good hiking boots and trekking poles, so that I could descend the rock trail quicker and save some energy for the climb up the tracks. Also had a long sleeve shirt and a hat with a neck protector, as I did get a bit sun burned the 2nd day. 
At 6' 2" and hiking down at a fast pace, I was able to get my time down from 60 mins to 50 mins, by the 6th day (down to the ghost town, but not detouring to the bridge). Some people run down portions of the trail, but when I did, it used too much energy, which was needed for the hike back up. 
The trek back up the tracks took me 1hr 15 mins the first day, but I was able to get it down to 52 mins, the last day. 
Not sure how accurate the health monitor is on my i-phone, but it showed 3.8 miles down the entire trail to the ghost town and .9 miles on the tracks back up as it is a straight shot up.
Be sure to bring water or some type of energy drink. 
Most of the local hikers wear regular sneakers to hike both portions, but it's very easy to twist an ankle on the rock trail down, so I prefer the hiking boots. 

Sorry to be so long winded, but I have really enjoyed the hikes.

By the way, you will see hikers, well into their 70's and 80's, which like the turtle and the rabbit story, sometimes know the best hike is slow and steady. 

Good Luck to all future hikers of the Barranca de Huentitan!

653118866.name: Nice walk, polluted river
653118866.author: a TripAdvisor user
653118866.reviewBody: Well worth a visit, good hike, many people do hill training (running) here. Great views. State of the river is very sad though, with piles of foam floating on top, rubbish hanging in trees in the riverbed. Water smells foul, looks extremely polluted.

646783370.name: Great walk
646783370.author: a TripAdvisor user
646783370.reviewBody:
Having read many comments about risk to safety and only to visit at the weekend when there is apparently police presence, I was a little apprehensive but we had no problems. We encountered around 30 people,  mostly beasting up and down the zigzag to keep fit.
We took an uber from our hotel and had no problem getting one to pick us up when we wanted to leave at the end of the afternoon. 
We took the main route down the winding cobbled zigzag path which took us over an hour. Then most people turn left and head downstream to the suspension bridge for great views and then return upstream past the down path to head for the steep climb back up the funicular,  passing the deserted town en route. 
We also turned left and headed downstream but crossed the river on the concrete bridge with the intention of walking to the lake upstream on the other side. We decided not to go that far as time was running short and we wanted to complete the walk before dark so when the path became unclear as it crossed a small pool we turned back downstream, passed the concrete bridge and headed for the suspension bridge which we then  crossed and headed back upstream  towards the concrete bridge. 
As we didnt want to crawl up the funicular railway track nor return using the main route we came down, we opted to take the steep path to the right shortly before the concrete bridge. It was really steep to start with turning to steep steps for about a third of the way but after that it got easier. Using google maps and google earth we were able to navigate when the path split. At the top the path was not clear but we followed the electricity lines to the start. That all took us 5 hours in total. Phew.

633405529.name: Wild Climb
633405529.author: a TripAdvisor user
633405529.reviewBody:
Most of the directions seem to be wrong. In order to get to the bridge you have to start at the top of the mountain. Entrance is at the end of the neighborhood, through a row of vendors. (I put: Barranca de Huentitán, Av. Belisario Domínguez 4446). 

It’s a steep climb down. No matter if you take the rocky path or the insane railroad trail. Once at the bottom where the river is turn left! If you turn right you are going to hit the railroad path. I didn’t know this until I went back up... so I missed the bridge :(

I took Uber from City Center. The driver expressed several times how dangerous it is and never to have my cellphone out unless I’m calling 911. He even stopped and asked a local for feedback and they said the same thing. However, I had no issue! I went solo and I’m as white as they come so I definitely didn’t blend in especially with 2 sleeves of tattoos. Lost of people climbing and running up/down the mountain so it’s very active. 

You’ll run into a lot of grave memorials, not sure if it’s from people dying due to the climb, violence (based off of the local driver) or just random plots. 

Attached are a few photos, one is a map showing the easiest route to the bottom as well as what it looks like from the river and from the top:

599671693.name: Unexpected hiking gem in the city
599671693.author: a TripAdvisor user
599671693.reviewBody: My son and I hiked the ravine on a Monday, and it was very pleasant and challenging. The information on the trailhead is a bit conflicting and confusing with multiple trailheads I think, but what we ended up doing was taking a 30 minute Uber from the city center to Av. Belisario Dom\u00ednguez 4446 (almost end of the street). There is a little park with vendors, you walk through that, take a right turn, and the trail starts. It is very well marked from there (we also downloaded the trail using wikiloc). We only went down to the river and back, which took about 45 minutes down and 2 hours up, with an approximate 2000ft elevation change. There were some folks going much faster than us though. The views were tremendous, with lots of birds and vegetation. There is also an cable railway that folks were using as an alternate trail, but this looked pretty hot and steep, and we were happier under the shade on the main trail. One interesting thing is there is a number marking system for every switchback turn - it starts at 1 at the top, and the last number we saw was 45 near the bottom. After number 30 the markings are irregular though.

583139479.name: Guadalajara\'s Grand Canyon
583139479.author: a TripAdvisor user
583139479.reviewBody: Oblatos\' Barranca (canyon) is really the Barranca of Huentitan--one of GDL\'s oldest and "bestest" neighborhoods. Mariachi king Vicente Fernandez is from there. The barranca is magical and a favorite for locals. Get there by taking the Macrobus along Calzada Independencia to the last stop. The canyon is all around you. As an added bonus, the neighborhood is quiet, safe, and home to the city\'s lovely zoo.

565346657.name: Lovely hike, amazing views, great exercise... and it is in Guadalajara itself!
565346657.author: a TripAdvisor user
565346657.reviewBody:
I am from Guadalajara and totally regret that I had not visited La Barranca before. This is such an amazing place and it is within the city. I had never expected that my lovely city had such a hike nearby. I’ve been living in Seattle for years, where people talk with pride about all the lovely hikes around. Never had I imagined that my own city had such a hidden jewel only half an hour away from my mom’s house.

La Barranca offers some beautiful views of the Rio Lerma-Santiago. It goes through a beautiful canyon like view. It makes you feel great to be out there while doing a walk or a hike. The simple fact of being out in nature with such amazing views is inspiring.

Some amazing friends kindly provided advice on how to approach the hike at the Barranca. It truly helped me, so I will outline it here for those who are interested in giving it a try. I know for sure that I will do this hike again soon, as I truly enjoyed it. I exercise regularly and when I have an opportunity to get my cardio in with an outdoor activity it is rewarding and more entertaining. Hate being in place looking at my reflection on a mirror for long periods of time.

Here are the tips to get the most out of the hike at La Barranca de Huentitan, which I truly recommend doing!

1. Get there early in the morning to complete the hike before it gets incredibly hot. We got there at 6am at the beginning of March. The way down is rocky and slippery. It was hard to see because it was still dark. I would recommend getting there exactly at sunrise. Check when sunrise is going to be and start at that time.

2. The way down takes approximately an hour and fifteen minutes. We all used sports shoes that can take on outdoors. There are a lot of rocks and it is slippery, so I would recommend taking an appropriate pace on the way down.

3. Once you get all the way to the bottom at river level, you will get to Y like intersection. You can either take a left or a right.
- If you take a left you will get to the bridge which has amazing views of the river and the canyon. The bridge is about 1.5km away from where you start. 
- If you take a right you will get to the uphill railway, which is the demanding part of this hike.

We personally took a left first and checked out the bridge. Which I truly recommend doing. If you are tight on time, then you can go straight to the right and get to the uphill railway.

4. For the uphill railway you must be very careful of where you step as you go up. I recommend brining sunblock and of course hydration. The hike is not easy. It is demanding if you are not used to it. There is part that is incredibly inclined, and you must use your hands to help yourself up. I recommend bringing gloves to prevent getting scratches, cuts and pull yourself up. Also, it is important to wear gloves in case there is any sort of bug. I must call out that there can sometimes be scorpions behind the rails, so just be careful about that. Nothing to worry about. Just common sense.

5. Most people call out taking about an hour and a half to get all the way to the top. I would say this is a fair assessment if you decide to take breaks. Hydrate yourself, eat a granola bar, have a banana. The main objective is to have fun, exercise and enjoy. Don’t try to push it to hard if you need a break. You’ll improve your times as you become more experienced.

6. There are parts of the hike where there are openings between the rails. Make sure that you are very careful as you go through these parts of the hike. Do not want to fall and end up injuring yourself.

7. There are 3-4 ways out as you are going up. That will take you to the same dirt road that brought you down. Have to call out though that once you start the biggest incline you are stuck in the path and have to finish or go back down. At this point though it is totally worth it to just finish. It is the most demanding but most fun part of the hike.

8. You can stop at any point to take pictures. Just make sure that if you are in a big incline that you sit down and turn around. You do not want to end up falling and rolling down for several meters.

9. Once you make it all the way to the top feel proud of yourself. You’ve made it. On your way out make sure to stop by the fruit stands to get a refreshing reward. There are stands that sell coconut water mixed with pineapple juice. It is called “Coco piña”. Totally recommend it. Refreshing and delicious.

It takes a total of 3 hours to complete the entire journey at a pretty good and safe pace. Make sure to get out there and give it a try. If you are from Guadalajara, this is a more entertaining way to exercise. If you are visiting and have the time, make sure to enjoy this fun and beautiful hike to add something different to your experience. I know that I will try to do this as often as possible.

555210979.name: Great for Hiking
555210979.author: a TripAdvisor user
555210979.reviewBody:
Beautiful ravine! Had a great time hiking down and up a different way. 

We put in about 4 hours and were on our ascent when my friend suffered from a significant cramp. Within 2 or 3 minutes, however, one of the horserider groups that we had seen elsewhere on the trail came up and offered us both a ride to the top of the ravine! They were a lifesaver and were more than happy to give me (a gringo) and my friend (a local) a lift on horseback for 30 minutes up some steep climbs that otherwise would have set us back for who knows how long. Very beautiful place and amazing people!

(As an aside, I had no idea how well horses can climb uphill!)

520105504.name: Nice hicking
520105504.author: a TripAdvisor user
520105504.reviewBody: This place is awesome to go for a hike jog our walk. Must due all of the mountain climbing down to the bottom and walking along rivers edge.

515601513.name: Amazing View
515601513.author: a TripAdvisor user
515601513.reviewBody: If you want some beautiful views and great pictures, you must go. \n\nMake sure you are at least in average shape since the walk back to the top can be tiring.

514990210.name: Beautiful, strenuous trail into a green canyon popular among sportive Mexicans during the weekend
514990210.author: a TripAdvisor user
514990210.reviewBody:
We went here for a run on Sunday morning at 9:00. Since there are several entries into the canyon, I need to clarify that we went for a trail run at the entry at the end of Av. Belisario Dominguez. From there we went straight down towards the Capilla de la Barranca de Huentitan. There I hid my plastic bag with water, towel and dry clothes and we started our trail run.
.
The first part of the path is through the forest and is completely paved with boulders and rocks and partly stairs. On your way down/ up there are several breathtaking views of the canyon through the canopy, and several lookout points for nice pictures. Later the path will become sand and run through shrubberies.

Even at 9:00 am it was already quite crowded with Mexicans going for a firm walk in their sports outfit. We ran down (careful because of the rocks and pebbles) and along the river towards the bridge (Puente Arcediano). Even near and on the bridge people were doing fitness, taekwondo, etc. We ran back a kilometer or so along the other side of the river until the path became narrower and people told us there was no bridge further upstream. We thus backtracked the same route and uphill until we were completely exhausted, soaked, and dried out. Luckily my bag was still there and I gulped my electrolyte drinks and put on dry clothes.. Completely upstairs, we bought big glasses of fresh juices (jugo) and took an Uber ride back to the hotel.

Although there are quite a few stalls selling drinks at the start and the first kilometer, there might only be one or two people selling drinks lower down into the canyon and none at the bridge. Bring your own.

Next to the path up/down, there is an old funicular track that some really fit people walk up.

511020748.name: Amazing view and killer work out
511020748.author: a TripAdvisor user
511020748.reviewBody: This was a three hour round trip hike that ends at the rio grande. The views were absolutely stunning! It\'s a popular locals hike and we got lapped by every age group who are out there just for fun. We made a mistake in not taking more water with us and felt dehydrated by the end. A local told us to go slow and he was right! The altitude can take a little out of you as well. I have bad knees and was worried about the rocky terrine but everything was fine. Just eat first, take snacks and lots of water!!!

495474864.name: GO AGAIN? Yes, great little hike and beautiful view.
495474864.author: a TripAdvisor user
495474864.reviewBody: GO AGAIN? Yes, This was a great little hike halfway down the canyon on a broken rock and cobblestone road. The ending at a chain-linked fence looking over to a waterfall coming from the city was good (you could not really go further). Half-way down is a long paved circular path for running and jogging. Wonderful views of the river and canyon. I walk fast, so it took me 30 minutes to walk down and 35 minutes back up. It is right behind the large police station. Took Uber there. Going back required waiting a bit until a Uber car was in the vicinity.

493122917.name: Very nice hike
493122917.author: a TripAdvisor user
493122917.reviewBody: DO AGAIN? Yes. This is a medium easy hike that took about 30 minutes to the fenced area by the waterfall and 35 minutes back up (I\'m a medium hiker and did not take any stops). I went mid-morning and there were many people, at least to the side, paved loop which was used for exercise. After that, there were fewer people. Taking the side loop might be nice, but I did not do this. My guess is that this was originally a road to what appears to be an abandoned, small power-generating plant, which is not directly accessible. It would be great to expand this hike down to the river. It was easy getting to the trail head right next to the police station using Uber. A bit harder using Uber to leave and I chose to cross the main highway to have a better option of getting a car.

467332334.name: An escape polluted by by the city above
467332334.author: a TripAdvisor user
467332334.reviewBody: I spend six weeks living in Guadalajara to improve my Spanish and had grown tried of city life. Barranca de Oblatos came up on my search of things to do around the city. It is located on the far side of the city near the zoo. To save money I took the mega bus toward the zoo and then used uber the rest of the way. However I would not recommend doing this. The mega bus is really crowded and overall it wasn\'t that much cheaper as Ubers are pretty cheap in Guadalajara. The entry point is near a police station and feels pretty awkward, but when you walk to the edge you see the massive canyon that you would\'ve never realized was bordering the city. The walk down is pretty long and there are often quite a few people running and spending family time. About a third of the way down there is a spot to jog, don\'t confuse this with the trail down, as it is just a loop. There are not many good vantage points until you get about two thirds of the way down. There is a wall that you can sit on with a clear view of the canyon below. The trail ends at a fence and a small building. You can\'t see the waterfall very good, so I tried to get closer and discovered the water was gray water from the city. Overall it was a good escape but I will probably always remember the foul odor of the water.

448579657.name: Also known as \'Barranca de Huentitan\', amazing hiking challenge !
448579657.author: a TripAdvisor user
448579657.reviewBody: Very good trip to do in winter season, it takes 1 or + hour to descend and 2 hours or more to climb up. Its a really good exercise you need to be prepared for, using running shoes, bringing water, going slow and stopping to enjoy the landscape. I have seen entire families with small children doing the trip, but I would not recommend to bring kids under 7 years.

437664031.name: A hard workout!
437664031.author: a TripAdvisor user
437664031.reviewBody: We went all the way down the hill. It was fun. The problem was going back to where we started. The best is the fresh aire. Beautiful nature.

434087937.name: Amazing nature, hardcore exercise spot
434087937.author: a TripAdvisor user
434087937.reviewBody: This place is amazing, even more so on the rainy season (Jun-Sept). It has numerous hiking trails; some easy and short, others grueling, steep and long. This is a great way to burn off some calories while marveling at the scenery and one of the steepest railways on the continent. If you\'re up to the challenge, and have at least decent stamina, you won\'t regret it (well, you may regret it the next day).Recommended.

420362982.name: Very wonderful hike, very green.
420362982.author: a TripAdvisor user
420362982.reviewBody: I come from Southern California. I am no stranger to a good hike. I was delightfully surprised by the green thick vegetation. Impressed by the many bright and colorful flowers that lined the rocky and at times very narrow trails. We traveled down the north less traveled trail. More difficult cause of the steep inclines and as it had rained it was slippery. Many of my companions had to walk on all fours for a small area toward the bottom. If it was dry I am sure it would have been easier. At the bottom we could see a large water fall to the left of the trail and a so small falls on the east cliff  wall. A nice pretty but dirty river mostly because of the rain and run off was visible but not easily accessed. Also a lovely bridge that is a replica of one that was built in the 1800\'s gave you access across. The route back we took was the longer less steep and much wider, main trail. I saw many animals along the trip. Stray feral cats, birds of all sizes from pigeons, black birds and hawks, also got a look at a large iguana sunning itself on a rock in the river. A great hike very moderate in difficulty and length. Highly recommend this if you want a good trail.

414049673.name: Stunning Canyon
414049673.author: a TripAdvisor user
414049673.reviewBody: I loved the view of the canyon. It\'s pretty spectacular. I got an Uber car out to the entrance, although I know buses go there too. There seem to be tents for homeless people when you start the descending trail. I heard warnings about safety, but when I went in the morning it seemed fine and there were loads of people doing the trail including families and elderly people. \n\nAs I\'ve said, the view of the canyon is spectacular. It\'s such a beautiful, natural place. I only walked about halfway down the trail. It\'s quite steep and approaching mid-day it was sweltering. I think I would have continued except for the heat but be warned that the steep walk back up is tough enough going. I think it\'s best to get there very early in the morning, maybe 8:00am or sooner. I would also recommend being careful on the cobblestoned path as it can be a bit uneven. All the same I would highly recommend this beautiful spot.

408522720.name: amazing vistas and great walk, good for fit people
408522720.author: a TripAdvisor user
408522720.reviewBody: There is a car park outside the entry.  And multiple bus routes to get there.  I think 631 takes you to the entry.   the walk is in two parts, downhill and then uphill.  If you go to the mirador consider walking back out if not fit.  Otherwise can become really strenous and very long walk up  steep hill.  the guardabosques are at the entry and can have a chat with them regarding walks and routes.  The main track is easy to follow, although not signed posted.  but most of the way has cobble stones.  You find different trails crossing, so be good to have a gps or a map if intending to attempt them.  You also cross a very steep train track which belongs to CFE (electricity company), there is a cable-train going down and up once a day.  Not really turistic, but might be worthed to ask for times, as if stock down there I have heard of them helping people out on the cable-car.Easy downloading an app in your phone that can track where you are, even if offline.  There is lots food at the top, Lechuguillas is a local specialty, Cactus juice, and you can even get 3 for 10 pesos as of June 2016. They come in 500ml and are great when you down in the canyon.  The river down there is somewhat smelly unfortunately.  Definitely no swimming in there.  I would advice a small day pack with 1.5 to 2L of water and some lechuguillas for sugar and energy, as well as Chocolate or palanquetas (bars with peanuts, amaranto, and honey) for energy.  Good walking shoes, the cobble stones give you a good run in your ankles, so good to take some firm shoes.  I even went down to the middle with my niece, 7 years old and was fine to do all herself.  We also went Summer (rainy season) so everything was green, river flowing and nice warmish weather.  Enjoy the walk

400379739.name: Nature Sports
400379739.author: a TripAdvisor user
400379739.reviewBody: Nice place to run or hiking just one recomendation, don\u00b4t carrie luxury tings like watches or jewerly and only visit it in the morning not to early and not lo late 8 to 13hrs preferible...

353128941.name: Disappointing
353128941.author: a TripAdvisor user
353128941.reviewBody:
How can I hide in a beautiful canyon be anything other than five points you asked?

+Unmarked trail leading to nowhere.
+Overflowing garbage cans.
+The faint sound of waterfalls with the smell of sewage.

I followed the cobblestone trail on its slow descent into the canyon.  Everytime I caught the faint sound of flowing water I also caught the distinct essence of sewage. 

The trail suddenly ended at a muddy, stinky fence. Off in the distance there was indeed a waterfall, but it was coming from the city.

301555964.name: One of my favorites in Guadalajara!
301555964.author: a TripAdvisor user
301555964.reviewBody:
The barranca is a must see when I visit family in Guadalajara. It is particularly beautiful during the rainy season (June-August). 

You need to be fit to make the 600m steep ascent. Go early morning, because it gets really hot after 11:00 am. Bring proper walking shoes, because you'll be walking on an uneven cobblestone trail. The main trails are safe to walk alone. I have never had any issues walking off-trail, but it is said that it is dangerous in the evening.

They have just built a beautiful new trail going down on a stairway, along the cliff and waterfalls down to the ancient bridge over the river. If you take the main trail (starting where Av. Belisario Dominguez ends) down to the 18th curve you will find the narrow beginning of this trail. If you follow the river up from the ancient bridge until the security post, you will find the main trail up again.

297520846.name: Great day hike in the Canyon near Guadalajara!
297520846.author: a TripAdvisor user
297520846.reviewBody:
Great hike! 600 meter change in elevation so it is good workout and I recommend that you go early in the morning when its cool! Wear good shoes as there are lots of rocks and a steep path.  Also take some water and a snack, though there are a few vendors at the top selling water and juices.  I went in the rainy season (in August) and it was green, lush with lots of flowers.  There is a public toilet (3$ MX) near the public parking lot.  I also saw a portapotty at the base, but was scared to go in there as it looked gross.  There are park gaurds at the base, but it seems pretty safe as there are lots of people working out on the path and many families there.  There is a way to get there and return by bus from downtown (sorry dont know number) and the stop was about 4 blocks from the entrance to the park.  The views are great, but the river is really polluted from upstream industry (arsenic, other heavy metals) according to my friend who works in the MX Environmental.

From wikapedia ... Barranca de Oblatos (English: Oblatos Canyon), also known as Barranca de Huentitán, is a canyon carved by the Río Grande de Santiago in Mexico in the state of Jalisco. It lies on the northeast side of the municipality of Guadalajara and on the edge of the municipalities of Tonalá, Zapotlanejo, Ixtlahuacán del Río and Zapopan in the Guadalajara Metropolitan Area. Its beauty and structure make it a slightly smaller scale version of the Grand Canyon in the United States, and Barranca del Cobre in Chihuahua.[1]

It includes approximately 1.137 hectares and it has an average depth of 600 meters. The difference in elevation between the rim of the canyon (1.520 msnm) and the river (1.000 mvsl) is 520 meters (1,706 feet) at the point of a funicular. This canyon is also named Oblatos-Huentitán due to the areas in the city crossed by it, called Oblatos and Huentitán respectively.

242620632.name: STEEP! But very scenic
242620632.author: a TripAdvisor user
242620632.reviewBody: I went to La Barranca with a local person, easily by city bus. There are vendors at the top selling juice, water, & snack. It is a steep hike to the bottom, paved with stones. Beautiful views over the canyon. We did not have time to walk to the bridge. Made the loop coming back, and caught the city bus again. Extremely steep. If you go, wear good walking shoes.

241005059.name: For The Hiking Enthusiast
241005059.author: a TripAdvisor user
241005059.reviewBody: You have two choices if you are visiting Guadalajara. First take a taxi or drive to a place that you can view the spectacular Barranca de Oblatos. If you are a hiking enthusiast and love adventure I would highly recommend a trek from the top to the bottom of this marvellous land form. I must warn you that the walk down is rather easy but the return trip is very difficult and it is not for the person who does not exercise/walk on a regular basis. I have made the trip on many occasions and several times I have had to wait on top for several hours for friends who were not prepared for the accent and had to stop numerous times to take a breath in order to go on. If you want to make an morning of it I suggest to bring a small lunch and enjoy it near the river. I love this place!

220883770.name: how to reach here
220883770.author: a TripAdvisor user
220883770.reviewBody: the macrobus blue colour on independencia will take you to barranca de oblatos.. it is the last station Mirador.. place is beautiful for sunrise and a lovely evening too.. 4 Peso fee..

206347453.name: They don\'t accept dogs
206347453.author: a TripAdvisor user
206347453.reviewBody: The view is awesome. It\'s a landscape ful of nature. What is really stupid is that they don\'t allow dogs. People go there for jogs or for a nice walk, and many of us would like to take our dogs. It\'s kind of retrograde not to allow them in. Anyway, I also rated it poorly because I\'ve been in Barranca de Huentitan and it a lot nicer (not sure if they allow dogs there). Also, at the bottom of it there\'s a small river with a waterfall. Nice view but it stinks so bad.\nThere\'s a bathroom facility, but was closed.

204363795.name: nice view, dangerous at night
204363795.author: a TripAdvisor user
204363795.reviewBody: nice view of this place, a place to exercise, relax and share with friends, be aware at night because it becomes very dangerous

146619749.name: La Barranca de Huentitan - great hike!
146619749.author: a TripAdvisor user
146619749.reviewBody: Great hike. It was a weekday not weekend as recommended by other reviewer but I felt completely safe, there were dozens of people there walking/running including several single women. At the top there are a few vendors of snacks and juices. I took a cab there but got the bus back to Guadalajara Centro from the trailhead for 6 pesos. Only issue was that at the bottom there was police keeping anyone from going further up or down the river, my Spanish wasn\'t good enough to fully understand what was up but from another post I gather construction of a dam is in progress. But that was the going to be the end of the hike anyway.

130711276.name: Nice views
130711276.author: a TripAdvisor user
130711276.reviewBody: But the river smells. Was hoping to hike around a bit but it was hard

123357427.name: Nice view
123357427.author: a TripAdvisor user
123357427.reviewBody: Its a place where people go on weekends\nThey have a water fall, and public pools

123270168.name: Oblatos Canyon
123270168.author: a TripAdvisor user
123270168.reviewBody: The Barrancas are sometimes a pain to drive through but the scenery can be spectacular...especially if you can find the waterfalls...sometimes hard to spot.

58450859.name: Excellent Scenery and fun hike- If you follow certain precautions
58450859.author: a TripAdvisor user
58450859.reviewBody:
I lived in Guadalajara for six years and went frequently to "la Barranca."  There are actually two popular entry points to see the Barranca - there is the "Barranca de Oblatos" and the "Barranca de Huentitan".   Both have beautifully scenic views that are especially spectacular during rainy season.   There are, however, some important things to keep in mind:

1) the Barranca is bustling with people on weekend mornings.  Many go there for a brisk walk.  It's great exercise but the path is rocky.  I would NOT recommend at all for anyone that is out of shape or has difficulty walking for any other reason. 

2) this is not in the best part of town.   I have been there many times alone as a young "gringa" and never felt at risk, but even locals don't recommend coming here during the middle of the day.  Make it down on a weekend morning or skip it.

3) I would not drive here - take a taxi.  Parking isn't great and it's not easy to know where to stop.    The entry can seem a bit hidden if you don't know what to look for.

4) If you are really up for a steep hike, ask the taxi driver to take you the "La Barranca de Huentitan"  (Again, only on a weekend morning)  This is where all of the serious exercisers come.  It's a beautiful and steep rocky downhill hike.  My absolute favorite place to work out EVER - not just in Guadalajara.   It's just a few miles away from Oblatos and so much more exciting, in my opinion.

670733556.name: Beautiful,  unique experience
670733556.author: a TripAdvisor user
670733556.reviewBody: Visiting it is an unique experience that one can have. The place seems to be well organised and with a beautiful architecture.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

670024261.name: Historical building. Active concert hall
670024261.author: a TripAdvisor user
670024261.reviewBody: Built in the 1870\'s - it is a stunning building and recognizable by its Classic facade with statues of the muses adorning its portico.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

668694374.name: gorgeous and historic concert hall
668694374.author: a TripAdvisor user
668694374.reviewBody: gorgeous and historic concert hall. Just got to view and the building is large and beautiful. Wish I could have heard a concert while I was there.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

668149114.name: Not on my top list
668149114.author: a TripAdvisor user
668149114.reviewBody: It\'s truly for people who rarely go to the theatre (or never, really) and who need to see red drapes, a large stage and many levels of golden moulding.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

635435039.name: The city\u2019s most colorful celebration of music, art and folkloric dance!
635435039.author: a TripAdvisor user
635435039.reviewBody:
If a trip to Guadalajara is in your future, plan it around the International Convention of Mariachi and Charrería  (Mexico’s unique national rodeo-like sport). During the city’s annual August convention of mariachi musicians, students, teachers, artists, fans and lecturers, thousands of mariachi performers and enthusiasts fill the plazas, theaters and streets of Guadalajara for the city’s most colorful celebration of music, art and folkloric dance.

Mexico’s top mariachi groups and many of the country’s best singers are featured in nightly performances at the Teatro Degollado where the skill of the musicians and their silver decorative buttons compete with the theater’s European-style baroque interior for the audience’s attention.

Tickets cost from US$30 to US$130 for the galas. If they are sold out, another favorite event is the Mariachi Mass on Sunday, September 2 at the Basilica of Zapopan, the home of the ancient statue of the Virgin Mary, the patron of Jalisco, Lake Chapala and Guadalajara.

Visitors to the city have many other opportunities to see the 50 or so groups perform. The official program includes a schedule of the daily concerts slated for a half dozen city shopping malls. Keep a sharp watch and be prepared to stop and enjoy pop-up and planned concerts in the city’s historic downtown plazas.

Mariachis, including all-female groups, attend from various Mexican states, and from countries around the world. This includes one group each from Sweden, Canada, Ecuador, Costa Rica, Cuba and Bolivia; five U.S. mariachi groups; three from Columbia; and, two groups from Peru.

Each year a different array of international groups makes the pilgrimage to Jalisco and all things mariachi. We’ve seen groups from Japan, Austria, France, Estonia and Paraguay, all delighted to be part of the colorful celebration of music, art and folkloric dance.

The festival ends next Sunday, September 2, so if you can’t make it this year, mark your calendars for next year!

By Judy King

616564677.author: a TripAdvisor user
616564677.reviewBody: Went to a great mariachi  concert with Mariachi  Vargas  and Mariachi de America, along with the Jalisco Philharmonic  orchestra. Needles to say, this was the best concert I have been to.  We had front  row seating and the backdrop of the teatro was perfect.. the acoustics were beyond reproach..it was nice to be in a piece of  history and be able to see the best mariachis  in the world..a note for those interested..the mariachi festival was held from August  20th through September 2nd...I Will return to this great experience..

563258459.reviewBody: Built in the mid-1800\'s, the Teatro Degollado was to fill a niche for a nice theater in those days. Now Guadalajara has plenty theaters but the Degollado is one of the most (if not THE most) notable one for its architecture and finesse of the interiors. Worth a few minutes to appreciate it and to go to the outside back of the building and visit the fountain of Guadalajara founders. \n\n... Of course worth even more if you get tickets for some events. We had the fortune to go to the Ballet Folklorico de la Universidad de Guadalajara and it was amazing! If you plan to travel to Guadalajara you should check if the Degollado has some upcoming shows of your liking and buy tickets ahead.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

551200541.name: World class venue, fantastic performance, gorgeous theatre!
551200541.author: a TripAdvisor user
551200541.reviewBody: If you have an opportunity to stroll around Guadalajara centro, include a visit of Degollado. Most days the doors are open for you to step in and look around the foyer and take in the majesty of the performance hall. The architecture is magnificent, with high columns, marble floors, loggias that look so inviting. I watched and listened to a famous pianist perform Franz Liszt once and I was brought to tears! The pianist himself confessed that he only plays encores in Guadalajara because he loves the people and their warm hospitality. There are restaurants and bars and shops all around, and so much to see in the historical downtown area. How fortunate we are to live only 1 hour away and be able to return to Degollado often.

address.streetAddress: Av. Hidalgo y Morelos Zona Centro

542097414.name: Total Sham - Robo
542097414.author: a TripAdvisor user
542097414.reviewBody:
This place is a total sham.
We bought very expensive tickets to a Mahler concert. We had the confirmation code, the confirmation email, the e-ticket and my ID proving I was the real buyer.
They still would not let us in because I did not have the credit card on me.
The lady in charge was arrogant and dismissive. She employed every bureaucratic mean to stop us from getting in.
Payed for the tickets, had the documents and still could not get in. Lost my money and the respect for this place.

529684439.name: A beautiful Rococo theatre
529684439.author: a TripAdvisor user
529684439.reviewBody: The Degollado is a beautiful little theatre right in the heart of Guadalajara. I highly recommend going to a philharmonic or other concert there day or night. It is located in the central plaza of Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico on Belen Street between Hidalgo Avenue and Morelos Avenue. Many performances (from cultural Mexican dances to international operas) take place in this building. Meant to be a monument of Guadalajara\'s culture, the theater was inaugurated in September 1866; breathing life to the city through its innovative artistic beauty (wikipedia).
