Whenver I have out of country guests I always take them to Latin Americas largest indoor market for a shopping experience of a lifetime. One, when I was Chrismas shopping, and wanted to buy a handbag I could find the design and color, but wanted a different shade of color the vendor brought me back several, from her competitors, to choos from. Although some people do not like the crowded atmosphere, it is a part of the total experience and besides the prices are right, the people are always friendly, the prices right. ENJOY!

58447225.name: Oldest Marketplace in North America - A Must See
58447225.author: a TripAdvisor user
58447225.reviewBody:
According to GDL history, native Americans were trading on this spot when the Spanish arrived.  It's popular, crowded and historical.  You can literally buy everything here from the newest electronics to the most traditional pottery.  You can stop for lunch and also do some grocery shopping.  

However, San Juan de Dios is not for the tourist that would prefer to sit at the bar drinking tequila and soaking up the sun.   It's for the adventure-seeker that likes to dive head-first into local history and culture.  The crowded, noisy atmosphre can make you uncomfortable if you're not prepared for it.   Have a good pair of walking shoes and a big shopping bag.  Be prepared to user your Spanish and compare prices when shopping.  If you're obviously from out of town you WILL be charged more.  Some might get offended at this, but look at it as a fun opportunity to negotiate in another language.  It's what Mexican shopping is all about. 

You can go and stay for 10 minutes or several hours.  Regardless of how long you are there, you should NOT miss this attraction.

12057438.name: Authentic shopping experience
12057438.author: a TripAdvisor user
12057438.reviewBody: It\'s a great experience just to wander through and get a little lost even. Definitely a market for the local people and not something just for tourists, hence don\'t expect a lot of souvenir shops (although there are some). Prices are low.\n\nBe sure to stop at the food court. As a foreigner speaking little Spanish it might feel a bit initimidating at first but the food is freshly cooked, prices are good, and service is friendly.

10653511.name: Market is worth checking out
10653511.author: a TripAdvisor user
10653511.reviewBody: My wife and I spent approx. 3 hours at the market and found it to be quite an authentic Mexican experience.  There is a ton to see as they sell almost anything you can imagine: there\'s an electronics section, a produce section, the "food court", clothing, holiday wares, jewelry, etc., etc., etc.  You can definitely get some deals here if you\'re a shopper.  You can also get some good, cheap food in the "food court" area, but you need to be a bit of an adventurous eater.  My wife wasn\'t a huge fan of the market and never got entirely comfortable- we walked in the produce/meat area on the 1st floor and our first impression of the market was the smell we were greeted to.  However, I found it quite interesting and enjoyable.

10064973.name: Uncomfortable
10064973.author: a TripAdvisor user
10064973.reviewBody: My mom and I just went there in the begining of October 07.  I was very uncomfortable.  The place is a maze where there are little stands crammed against one another selling bootleg cds, dvds and knock off shoes among other things.  The aisles are very narrow and a lot of the men seemed to stand in the way enough that they made it necessary to rub against me in order for me to get by.  I didn\'t feel completely safe and we got left as soon as we could find a way out.   For shopping go to Tlaquepaque (if that is spelled right) stores there are very nice and you can find everything from ceramics to art work.

1228615.name: Bring a wheelbarrow
1228615.author: a TripAdvisor user
1228615.reviewBody: When you go to the libertad, you are not governed by how much money you should take...but how much merchandise you are able to carry. The 2 and 3 story complex has everything from pigs feet to Nike shoes and everything in between. A bustling complex of humanity and commerce which has the motto: If we dont have it, we\'ll go run and get it. Just dont cut yourself short, give yourself plenty of time to systematically work yourself through. I wanted a leather vest and the store/cubbyhole that I patronized had the right color but no the right style. When she found the style, it was the wrong color. Then theres the right size. So off she ran to who knows where to get what I was looking for. She worked so hard that when I did get what I was wanted, I didnt even haggle or bargain. In fact I gave her an additional tip. Guess Im getting soft in my old age. But what a nice group of people, both patrons and storekeepers. Have fun and after you do, go take a carriage ride and remember this isnt New York\'s Central Park, its the Libertad, Guadalajara, MX.

654571481.name: Statute in a very busy roundabout
654571481.author: a TripAdvisor user
654571481.reviewBody: I understand this statute is important to the city but the frustrating part is actually trying to get to it.  The roundabout reminds of an European one where it is impossible to cross.  I recommend an underground stairwell.  Nice to see and close to the arches.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

643879326.name: Beautiful statue
643879326.author: a TripAdvisor user
643879326.reviewBody: This is a beautiful statue with an artistic horse sculpture on the grounds of the glorietta. If you are traveling in the area, it is worthwhile take a trip around the glorietta, but otherwise, it is one of many in Guadalajara.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

612739183.name: Guadalara\'s guardian
612739183.author: a TripAdvisor user
612739183.reviewBody: She is so large and beautiful, surrounded by lovely landscaping. We only had a chance to drive by, but we\'ve heard this is a gathering spot on Sundays, when the streets are shut down.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

611725787.name: Lovely
611725787.author: a TripAdvisor user
611725787.reviewBody: The traffic around this monument is very busy...be careful...LOVED the horse sculptures behind Minerva...loved the way the water boils and the mist flies around the monument...be careful of the traffic!!!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

609019416.name: Beautiful Minerva
609019416.author: a TripAdvisor user
609019416.reviewBody: Beautiful great statue of Minerva. Wish I could have taken a better picture as our taxi drove past. There was heavy traffic when we drove by.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

590737908.name: Iconic place
590737908.author: a TripAdvisor user
590737908.reviewBody: This is a most visit if you are in Guadalajara there is a big garden in the center of the street and an iconic monument with water fountains this is a very pretty place.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

539167476.name: Beautiful, but not a tourist attraction..
539167476.author: a TripAdvisor user
539167476.reviewBody: It\'s a beautiful statue, great to look at while you\'re driving, but it\'s not really an attraction you can visit.. It\'s more of a decoration than a place to visit

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

533545731.name: One of the Wonders of Guadalajara!
533545731.author: a TripAdvisor user
533545731.reviewBody: It\'s always a pleasure to see this statue in the middle of the Glorieta (roundabout) in one of the most pleasant parts of the city. The one bad thing I could say would be when they block this area off for special events (or demonstrations), but it\'s still worth a drive or a walk to see it, even at night.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

530908365.name: Take a drive by the Minerva when in Guadalajara
530908365.author: a TripAdvisor user
530908365.reviewBody: You can view this in five minutes from your car, so schedule a drive by so you can see La Minvera and other of the interesting "gloriettas" or roundabouts of Guadalajara. Occasionally, there are festivities at La Minerva too; then the streets will be closed to traffic and you and your family or friends can walk about and enjoy whatever event that is happening, usually for no entrance fee.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

504312010.name: Iconico
504312010.author: a TripAdvisor user
504312010.reviewBody: I love because every time that I go to visit there is some different about Monument an it very close Los Arcos

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

462798543.name: Nice to See
462798543.author: a TripAdvisor user
462798543.reviewBody: The Statue of Minerva is neat to see.  At night they have the statue lit up and it looks really neat.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

454117961.name: Great Statue but Lost in Traffic
454117961.author: a TripAdvisor user
454117961.reviewBody: The statue is fantastic all the area around it is bustling with life. Unfortunately theres way too much traffic to do anything more than drive by it or see it from a nearby building.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

452212814.name: hotel area
452212814.author: a TripAdvisor user
452212814.reviewBody: was under construction, but looks amazing view,clean,100 percent safe area,many restaurant near, tourist area

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

440515805.name: Best to see early Sunday morning
440515805.author: a TripAdvisor user
440515805.reviewBody: There is an enormous amount of traffic around the Glorieta Minerva and too hard to walk to the center to see ithe statue of goddess Minerva unless it\'s early on a holiday or Sunday morning. It is currently under reconstruction (November 2016)

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

437634367.name: Inspiring spot !
437634367.author: a TripAdvisor user
437634367.reviewBody: I see Minerva very very often. Standing still always protecting the big-city. \nThe government just hired not long ago experts to keep her in shape. The gardens around are just divine !

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

434077102.name: One of the city\'s icons
434077102.author: a TripAdvisor user
434077102.reviewBody: This is perhaps the image by which Guadalajara is mostly known. It is indeed very beautiful, and is near restaurants, malls and attractions. On Sunday mornings streets are closed to automobile traffic and can be visited by bicycle.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

428252285.name: Very popular Landmark
428252285.author: a TripAdvisor user
428252285.reviewBody: Maybe this is the most known monument for locals. The statue is beautiful and represents the city protector. My feeling is that every administration would like to change it somehow so there is no constant view of this monument. Thay have changed the garden many times even the street around. It is a momument to be seen from a car but now you can walk around on sunday mornings.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

407641397.name: A Greek Goddess adds class
407641397.author: a TripAdvisor user
407641397.reviewBody: A wonderfull trafic circle in front of the fiesta americana hotel that is a syble of this fine city currently undergoing a face lift

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

407348142.name: Photo opp only
407348142.author: a TripAdvisor user
407348142.reviewBody: This is another of Guadalajaras famous monuments.  There really isnt a nice place to get a picture because its in a traffic circle.  Snap the photo on the fly as you drive around

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

381781836.name: Guadalajara\'s most notable landmark
381781836.author: a TripAdvisor user
381781836.reviewBody: This is a beautiful glorieta (when the traffic isn\'t bad) and adds a little history as this area used to be the "entrance" to the city when it was much smaller so, so many years ago.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

377198262.name: Worthwhile place to go \'if\' you stay around there
377198262.author: a TripAdvisor user
377198262.reviewBody: Minerva is the Roman goddess of wisdom. As far as what I\'ve searched, there is no special story in the creation of this statue, compared to other sculptors in many famous cities.\nThus, I\'d like to recommend to visit and see it only for the people whose hotel is nearby.\nThere is a cafe around the Minerva, called \'cafebarracafe\' with a small terrace. Walking to the place and enjoying cofee on the terrace and the view from it would be worthwhile.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

370173704.name: A Wonderful Heart for Guadalajara
370173704.author: a TripAdvisor user
370173704.reviewBody: Minerva means a lot to this city. Originally they dod not like or approve of the depiction of her, but have grown to see her as representing the city. You don\'t visit Minerva - you drive around her in a traffic circle. Sometimes the road is closed for important events. I heard that if there is a major topic for the people to discuss, nobody asks where it will be - everyone just shows up at the Minerva statue!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

362670901.name: Mist and Spray in the Middle of the Traffic Circle
362670901.author: a TripAdvisor user
362670901.reviewBody: Great to ride by or stroll by on Sundays.  On the westside of the city, it\'s where the via recreativa ends.  Most days it\'s an island surrounded by shark infested waters -- that its, unrelenting traffic makes it impossible to enjoy from a pedestrian\'s point of view.  But on that one day of the week, Sunday until 2:00 pm., this "Glorieta" is worth a spin.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

360176064.name: Cars and more cars!
360176064.author: a TripAdvisor user
360176064.reviewBody: There\'s nothing much to recommend about Minerva.  The neighbourhood is great but the actual monument is difficult to see or access because of the constant roaring traffic that surrounds it.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

353715293.name: Beautiful statue
353715293.author: a TripAdvisor user
353715293.reviewBody: This is a statue in the middle of a round about.  You can see it at a distance but the opportunity to get up close is not there.  The fountain around it is impressive when it is running,  but seems to be switched off sometimes. It is a very busy path for cars so you will have the constant traffic of you view this.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

353000105.name: Beautiful roundabout
353000105.author: a TripAdvisor user
353000105.reviewBody: Powerful misting fountains surround this statue. This interesting attraction is in a busy roundabout. Watch your rear view mirrors as you admire the beauty or you will crash.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

352208291.name: Beatiful Statue
352208291.author: a TripAdvisor user
352208291.reviewBody: You can visit this beautiful statue if you buy a ticket at the Plaza (Downtown) in a Tapatio Tours. Take you to Guadalajara Downtown

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

351343981.name: Sympolic Foutain of Guadalalaga
351343981.author: a TripAdvisor user
351343981.reviewBody: La Minerva is one of the largest and most fountains in Guadalajara. Its located outside the City center and usually youll pass it while driving towards the Expo Guadalajara area. While the Minerva is nice I personally would not go out of my way to visit it. Its a Big rotanda usually with lots of traffic making it hard to visit on foot. Sometimes at night is has pretty lights or Christmas decorations during the Holidays.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

342462332.name: Statue that means so much to the local - very proud
342462332.author: a TripAdvisor user
342462332.reviewBody: This status, as other noted, is in the middle of a round-about. It is rather large and a place that when something good happens, becomes a collection place for the locals to celebrate. I was there Jan 22, 2016 and there was some scaffolding on one-side. It did not take away from the effect though. If you can plan it in your route, I highly suggest driving buy.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

333380937.name: Statue, Park, Memorial all in one
333380937.author: a TripAdvisor user
333380937.reviewBody:
This statue is impressive in size and the fountain is beautiful.  It is also, as others have said, kind of a central figure for Guadalajara.  If you are driving about on your own it is likely a local person will give out directions relative to Minerva Roundabout.

For the U.S. driver, also, it is impressive to see a five-lane-wide traffic circle.

It's great to see, but there's nothing to "do" there.  Just drive by and observe.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

327677248.name: Non stop site
327677248.author: a TripAdvisor user
327677248.reviewBody: you CAN stop a few blocks near, but if there is regular traffic it will be impossible to get a closeup, unless traffic is being deviated, and it DOES happen also, it is a nice spot to get a memory picture and its surrounded by restaurants, car agencies, drugstore and a bowling ale.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

316067399.name: An impressive monument
316067399.author: a TripAdvisor user
316067399.reviewBody: The statue is impressive in size and seems to be emblematic in the city of Guadalajara. It is almost as you have not been to Guadalajara if you don\'t go by the Minerva. Is located in the middle of a traffic circle so enjoying it must be somewhat of a quickie thing. Locals are very proud and proud of their monument so the seem to make an effort to show it off. It is best appreciated at night when it is lit with colorful lights. One interesting detail is that it has lots of agave plants on the grounds. Agave is the source for making tequila an Jalisco State one of the few that can officially produce the product. Certainly worth seeing.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

309182263.name: Centerpoint of all directions in Guadalajara
309182263.author: a TripAdvisor user
309182263.reviewBody: If you have to meet someone and you\'ve never been in Guadalajara, this is definitely the easiest point to reach from airport, bus station, downtown, nightlife area, Zapopan, etc. It is a huge round-shaped square with a great fountain in the middle. And right atop the fountain stands the "hunting Diana" welcoming visitors to central Guadalajara. Around it are the huge Fiesta Americana hotel, the Mercedes Benz car dealer and one of the nicest Starbucks I have ever seen, beacuse it has a little roof garden from where you can enjoy your coffee and Guadalajara\'s nice weather while you are sipping your coffee.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

237032963.name: Great monument in a great location - poor maintenance
237032963.author: a TripAdvisor user
237032963.reviewBody: This is one of the city\'s best monuments. It is more impressive when driving by it at night because of the lights and the water feature. Unfortunately, some times the city fills the surroundings with advertisement or the water feature is off which makes the monument look not as impressive as it can be.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

236943549.name: Another falic monument
236943549.author: a TripAdvisor user
236943549.reviewBody: Well, I don\'t know much about Minerva, but I took a double decker bus tour around the city and got a photo of Minerva.  I would recommend the double-decker bus ride because I saw things I never would have seen otherwise.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

226484923.name: Just if it is on the way.
226484923.author: a TripAdvisor user
226484923.reviewBody: Not much to do there. If one is near, then go take a look do not take a special trip. It is interesting that Guadalajara some how took Minerva as a mascot!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

223531597.name: Better seen when travelling by car or bus
223531597.author: a TripAdvisor user
223531597.reviewBody: Not too impressive for me... I would rate between 2 and 3 stars. It is at the centre of a roundabout with lots of very carefully planted agave all around and a water feature which adds interest to the place. Just drive by to see it... not worth if you need to get there on foot!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

221468190.name: I love this woman
221468190.author: a TripAdvisor user
221468190.reviewBody: Not sure why, but I love this statue.  My favorite in the world since my mother told me it was a girl when I was little.  I woman with a shield and sword.  What?  I like her !!  The city does a great job of keeping her and the fountain in great shape.  Love her !!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

218705647.name: nothing fancy
218705647.author: a TripAdvisor user
218705647.reviewBody: crowded traffic circle not worth a sight, the statue is not interesting but the water sprout is welcome

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

195612901.name: Not worth your time
195612901.author: a TripAdvisor user
195612901.reviewBody: It literally is just a mythological statue of Minerva in the middle of a very busy round about. Nothing more, nothing less.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

195011079.name: Nice Neighborhood
195011079.author: a TripAdvisor user
195011079.reviewBody: We found a good restaurant near here, and enjoyed meandering in the sun near La Minerva. Still in the city without being downtown, so it was nice to see a few different things.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

189531816.name: Butch woman
189531816.author: a TripAdvisor user
189531816.reviewBody: This huge metal statue is right out of Greek Mythlogy.  A very big  daughter of Zues, looks over the west side of this big city!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

168774252.name: Dont waste your time
168774252.author: a TripAdvisor user
168774252.reviewBody: it is not the "great thing", dont bother to look at it. You will see anyway the Minerva when you go anywhere, because is  at the center of GDL.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

158866697.name: Good view
158866697.author: a TripAdvisor user
158866697.reviewBody: average place to visit, but I found a TACOS place next to this place and was nice... cheap and tasty.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

150448545.name: Loved to see her at least twice a day she is an inperation to all Of those who gaze upon her.
150448545.author: a TripAdvisor user
150448545.reviewBody: Make acces to go to her and take a proper photo of her. Again educate your visitors. at least three languages engish german and chinese

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

146111313.name: What an awsome part of the Mexican heritidge to see!
146111313.author: a TripAdvisor user
146111313.reviewBody: This was such an awsome center area to visit and hang out in.  Lots of food.drinks around to relax also

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

144028662.name: A very visible historical landmark of the city.
144028662.author: a TripAdvisor user
144028662.reviewBody: This extra large statue of the Roman goddess Minerva, is well recognized not only for it\u00b4s cental location that devides the East and West sides of the city of Guadalajara, but for it\u00b4s new rennovation to make the streets that encircle it much wider.  This allows for it to be used as a public venue for speaches, concerts and many social events that is easy to get too.  It has also been recently adopted as the new picture you will see on all new Jalisco state, licence plates, spreading it\u00b4s fame throughout the country!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

142315128.name: A statue in a big traffic circle. Maybe worth a photo from the car.
142315128.author: a TripAdvisor user
142315128.reviewBody: It is located at an intersection of major national highways, so it will be busy around the statue. If it is on your way to something else, drive by it and snap a photo, but don\'t count on spending much time there.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

142088860.name: It\'s a Statue
142088860.author: a TripAdvisor user
142088860.reviewBody: Not something you walk to, it\'s a traffic circle. More of a looky-loo in your taxi as you drive by. Beautiful at night, pride of the city.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

141882019.name: is a nice place
141882019.author: a TripAdvisor user
141882019.reviewBody: you cannot stop to take pictures or seesight walking traffic is very intense it is missing  atunnel as in the arch of triunph of paris can you imagin that place if you had to vist walking throgh the car traffic, well that is what happens in the minerva fountain

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

138975265.name: iconic!!
138975265.author: a TripAdvisor user
138975265.reviewBody: This icon of Guadalajara is one of the most beautifull sculptures in GDL, it is hard to cross the street to see it but still worth it to go and drive around

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

136261272.name: one of Guadalajaras must see sights
136261272.author: a TripAdvisor user
136261272.reviewBody: must pass this lovely monument 10 times a day when I am in Guadalajara. more charming than ever with the new pavement, installed last year.  GO at night to see how busy the streets are at 11pm

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

133884173.name: This monument it\'s alive!
133884173.author: a TripAdvisor user
133884173.reviewBody: With beautiful landscape and fountains this lady rules that road where she lives! Amazingly tall and beautiful. Don\'t miss it!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

131566626.name: Exellent night Life
131566626.author: a TripAdvisor user
131566626.reviewBody: Best looking people on all Mexico are here!! go out aroun11pm and you\'ll forget where you are.  just great time here

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

129070834.name: Symbol of the city
129070834.author: a TripAdvisor user
129070834.reviewBody: You can only drive by this icon of the city. It is a traffic circle or "glorieta" but is a beautiful fountain in what is considered the new city center. Used to be the entrance of the city, along with "Los arcos"

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

123265620.name: Minerva
123265620.author: a TripAdvisor user
123265620.reviewBody: She used to be at the entrance/exit of the city (before Vallarta was made one way...and city expanded) and not only beautiful but I have great memories of parties there...whenever the Chivas play, win or lose, they always have a big celebration there.  Chivas: local soccer team of the University of Guadalajara.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

122244686.name: Look Quick as Driving By
122244686.author: a TripAdvisor user
122244686.reviewBody: The traffic is so worth your life that if you are driving, forget trying to see it. Passengers can catch a quick view. It\'s just something interesting to see.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

122047240.name: This is a traffic circle.
122047240.author: a TripAdvisor user
122047240.reviewBody: This is a traffic circle on Avenida Lopez Mateos, on one of the busiest streets on the west side of Guadalajara. They have concerts there every once in a while and it\'s where the soccer fans go to celebrate after a big victory. In the middle of the circle is a statue of Minerva, Roman goddess of wisdom...a fitting symbol for a town that has so many universities.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Lopez Mateos y Avenida Vallarta

675363934.name: So much Mexican History touring the island should be on all Mexicans MUST VISIT list
675363934.author: a TripAdvisor user
675363934.reviewBody:
Amazing! We weren’t informed on getting our own tour guide and thought we would hire one at the island! BIG MISTAKE! The island has only a Security/ Mexican Federal guarding the island. We did find a boat round trip to the island at the Chapala Malecon. ALWAYS NEGOTIATE, Mexican negotiate with prices and will work with you as long as the price is reasonable. We thought the $2000 Mexican Pesos was fair, Miguel our boat guide informed us that the island had no stores or water, he offer to do a a run to a local store for us to buy us water and beer for our 45 minute boat ride. 
The island is so Amazing, even with our a guide we kinda guided ourself around. 
MAKE SURE TO WEAR COMFY HIKING SHOES. Our 5 year old toddy had a great time walking and exploring the island. He had fun trying to chase the cats that seem to have invaded the island. 
One room entering the fort to the fight by the steps to walk up to top, made me feel very uncomfortable like something was there! I feeling of sadness. I took picture and a lady seems like face Appeared. 
A great adventure, would love to go back but hiring a guide.

660003345.name: Very Interesting Visit to a Historic Site in Mexican History
660003345.author: a TripAdvisor user
660003345.reviewBody:
My wife and I visited a couple of longtime friends who have been living on Lake Chapala, the largest lake in Mexico, an hour south of Guadalajara.   On our last day, we drove along the north shore of the lake to Mezcala, almost exactly half way along the north shore of the 50-mile-long lake.

We hired a guide and a boat to take us out to Isla de Mezcala, about 5 miles off shore, to explore the the island, learn about its place in history, and explore the ruins.  The island was used by early people of the area for ceremonial purposes.   Later a small chapel was built on the island.   But the island’s place in history is assured by its significance in the history of the struggle for Mexican independence.  The island was successfully defended by indigenous people against a far superior force of Spanish soldiers in the Spanish/Mexican war in the early 1800s.  Many years later the Mexican government built a prison on the island to house the worst of their prison population.

The island is a very worthwhile expedition and well worth the time and money to go there.

657279331.name: Do not miss this
657279331.author: a TripAdvisor user
657279331.reviewBody:
What a day!
Breakfast Tacos at the Barbacoa on the carretera in Ajijic then on to Mexcala to hire a guide and a boat to go to the ruins on Isla de Mezcala. 

My friends and I got incredibly lucky in hiring Jose, an english speaking local man with an interesting story, whose knowledge of the history of the struggle for Mexican independence, the local Indian culture and the treasures hidden around Mexcala made our day extraordinary.    

Jose took us through the ruins making the history come alive, citing the generals involved, the villages involved - physically pointing to them as we stood at elevated vantage points, important dates, significant moments and locations and above all how the people of Lake Chapala were not defeated by the Spanish but betrayed.   

After we returned to Mexcala, Jose offered to take us to see Petroglyphs that we never would have found on our own, confirming that the Mexican people and culture are eternal 

It was a day we’ll never forget largely due to the guide we were lucky enough to find.
I’m including his number because he brought history alive as few could.

Jose C.   Cell:   33-14-25-0753

641947333.name: What a history!
641947333.author: a TripAdvisor user
641947333.reviewBody: My wife, 2 kids and myself went to Mezcala Island for a visit and to learn about some of the history of the area. Our guide - Jose - spoke very good English and shared the history of the island as well as of the area. His family is from the area and told us some very interesting stories from the 1800s onward. You catch a boat from the docking area and it\'s a 10 minute ride to the island. The walk is a bit rocky and tough but you go at your pace or as time allots.

629855944.name: Worth the price if the temperature is cool
629855944.author: a TripAdvisor user
629855944.reviewBody: We had an informative tour of the island fort, and a nice boat ride to and from the island.  The little restaurant at the dock area served cold cervesa and good chops and guacamole ( chunky avocado).\n\nI think it was worth the cost ($4000 pesos & tip), and the effort.

559853746.name: Historical  Fort 1800\'s
559853746.author: a TripAdvisor user
559853746.reviewBody: This island housed a fort which held off the Spaniards in 1821. The war lasted four years and it was the indigenous insurgents who cleverly held off the Spaniards from taking what was rightfully their land. Following the war, the Spaniards became friends and helped the indigenous people with resettlement. Years later Mezcala island became a prison and house nearly 800 or more inmates. Today the buildings are restored. It costs 350 pesos to go across and there is a small museum in the town of Mezcala with unique artifacts supporting historical findings. I would love to see employees in period costume working and living the life as it was 200 plus years ago. I think it would attract many tourists while stimulating the local economy. They is a chapel and tannery next to the fort. A must see!

500757216.name: Historical island in Lake Chapala, Jalisco,
500757216.author: a TripAdvisor user
500757216.reviewBody: Mezcala, located  in the the largest freshwater lake of Mexico, has played a significant role throughout the history of Mexico. Some of the old fortifications, quarters and church still remain. The island can be reached for a few pesos by boat from the village by the same name on the shore of the lake, east of Chapala.

486892008.name: very historical, more than you would think
486892008.author: a TripAdvisor user
486892008.reviewBody: Have been here 5 times over the years and every year the people from Mezcala make it better they are constantly renewing and cleaning, it would be nice to have more plaques explaining all the different buildings

445730699.name: Great Historical Site
445730699.author: a TripAdvisor user
445730699.reviewBody: Nicely preserved. Take a boat to get there and highly recommend Xavier with Xaobe Tours. Interesting history from period when 1000 indigenous held off 8,000 Spaniards, to fortification, to rebellion during independence period to prison.  A must see!

431575988.name: Prison history
431575988.author: a TripAdvisor user
431575988.reviewBody: I thought the trip to the island was worth while and I found it to be very interesting with the history behind it.  I would recommend a trip there and see where the prisoners were kept.  It reminded me of Alcatraz Island in San Francisco, CA

418271247.name: Independence war memorila Island
418271247.author: a TripAdvisor user
418271247.reviewBody: Easy to visit by boat that you can take from the nice Mezcala small town "Embarcadero", about 15 miles feast rom Chapala town.

349509970.name: Real wilderness
349509970.author: a TripAdvisor user
349509970.reviewBody: While Ajijic is a better known town on the beautiful lake Chapala, this quaint little city a little away really provides you a flavor of the original native - spanish interactions that may have taken place in this country. The Presidio islands with the spanish military base (and the place where the Mexican war of independence was fought), is a real wilderness but very, very beautiful! You either reach there by motor boat or by a kayak (will take longer). The Island is about 25 hectares in length and breadth and is really beautiful! The ruins of the military ramparts can be explored!

286465896.name: Little Known History
286465896.author: a TripAdvisor user
286465896.reviewBody:
Mezcala is a sad little town, so be prepared.  If you take the bus from Chapala you will get off when you see the twin towers of a church, about 45 minutes.  Walk down the main street hill till you reach the lake.  We were accosted by a teen wanting to be our guide--nice kid but we didn't need a guide.
There's a sign on the shore with rates and offerings.  The boats in the area have formed a collective with standardized prices.  300 pesos to get out to the island and have an hour, more for longer trips or tours.
We spent an hour there and it was enough.  Can't explore on your own which was disappointing, but part of the ruins are being excavated for pre-hispanic artifacts and are off limits.
New signage in both English and Spanish explaining what you see.  I had read up on history before coming so the running commentary from guide was unnecessary but he was knowledgeable.  
The island is simply beautiful, even if you don't care much about Mexican Revolution history.  Amazing views of Lake Chapala.

250814643.name: Amazing place
250814643.author: a TripAdvisor user
250814643.reviewBody: Not what I expected at all. A full fort on Mescala Island! Dating from 1812 War of Independence. Recently restored as a tourist attraction yet no one goes. Easy to reach by car or bus from Chapala and Ajijic. Take a flashlight as the site is not lit. No souvenir stand either, so take water.  Can easily be seen in 2 hours or so and tip the young school boy even if you don\'t understand Spanish!

128018307.name: Great if your are into history
128018307.author: a TripAdvisor user
128018307.reviewBody: Went with someone very knowledgeable about the history of the island.  We visited during sping break, and it was not crowded.  You have to take a short boat ride and you\'re there.  We split the cost of the boat with another group.  If your speak Spanish there are tour guides available, usually a young kid who works for tips.  My cousin who is a teacher and went along and quizzed the kid and he got all his facts right!  Before heading to the island we also visited a small museum in town, that talks about the history of the island and it\'s native peoples.  Bring water along it is hot and there is limited shade.  It was in the high 70s in April.

125520961.name: A great piece of history that Mexicans should be proud of!
125520961.author: a TripAdvisor user
125520961.reviewBody: We drove from Ajijic to the little town of Mezcala, parked right near the plaza and walked down the the lake. The people we were traveling with had been before and had a name of a guide who we asked for when we got to the pier. They called him and he was there in about 5 minutes. The boat ride over was 300 pesos roundtrip and our guide told us to pay him whatever we felt he was worth. The trip over was super calm and a very nice boat ride..and we all were given life jackets just in case. It was very quiet for tourists although there was a big mexican family having a family day near the dock. The guide (Cesar) spoke pretty good English and told us all about each section of the walk ensuring we didn\'t miss anything including the big tree  on the way in and even how the land across the water looks like a crocodile from afar! The \'buildings\' are being restored and the guide told us about the church, jails and even the captains quarters. A great way to spend a day! I would highly suggest going with a guide..ours was only 18 but was very professional and knew the great history of this neat place.

123270412.name: Mezcala Island
123270412.author: a TripAdvisor user
123270412.reviewBody: Getting there is the biggest problem since even when the lake is calm in a small boat the passengers in front usually get wet...and not that much on the island to do except sight see over rough ground.

122046265.name: Renovation complete
122046265.author: a TripAdvisor user
122046265.reviewBody: This is an island in Lake Chapala a few miles off shore from the village of Mezcala. The island was the refuge of a group of insurgents in Mexico\'s War of Independence. Later it served as a prison.  The restoration of the fort and prison is well done and only recently completed. If you make your way to newly renovated town docks in Mezcala, you\'ll find a number of boats willing to take you to the island for a reasonable fee. Mezcala is small and you can see the lake; just go to the plaza and turn right. Once on the island, facilities are non-existent.

122000794.name: Nestled in the middle of Lake Chapala
122000794.author: a TripAdvisor user
122000794.reviewBody: This beautiful island is a must see for any visit to the Lake Chapala area. It has great historic significance. It can be reached by boat which can be hired onshore.\n

63167260.name: great
63167260.author: a TripAdvisor user
63167260.reviewBody: the island is claimed by 2 states,it at one time was the state prison for both of these states.it is now in a phase of reconstruction as a tourist attraction.take the boat from the village of mezcala as the drive from chapala is very nice.

1484773.name: loved
1484773.author: a TripAdvisor user
1484773.reviewBody: I like the expirience! it was a new and wonderful thing to do around the Lake Chapal a rea and would recomend the visit to other tourists.

673500015.name: Beautiful street with arts? crafts and restaurants
673500015.author: a TripAdvisor user
673500015.reviewBody: This is for sure a beautiful street with arts and crafts, more of them for the tourists. But is a beautiful street and you can find beautiful restaurants and original places. I liked so much to visit the free gallery of Sergio Bustamante, an original gallery with lots of unique masterpieces, and to eat at Casa Luna, even if it was a bit expensive I can say it worth the cost .

654581295.name: Tlaquepaque at its finest retail - love it!
654581295.author: a TripAdvisor user
654581295.reviewBody: This street was quite impressive and loved that it was very pedestrian friendly.   The storefronts are very unique; the architecture, the restaurants and shops were fabulous. So fabulous, that many don\'t want you taking photos of their masterpieces.

642930692.name: Safe Day and Evening Pedestrian Street
642930692.author: a TripAdvisor user
642930692.reviewBody: We spend two days walking around Tlaquepaque and Calle Independencia.   Place is crowded at night yet safe, street stands galore and crafts markets in abundance.  Some of the finest Talavera pottery, day of the dead artisans are found here.  Mariachi music at El Patio and El Parian nightly.   So if you are looking for fun family friendly place along with food, drinks and music, Tlaquepaque is the place.  Favorite part of our visit to GDL.

621187460.name: A nice stroll down the street
621187460.author: a TripAdvisor user
621187460.reviewBody: The street itself is very pleasant, a lot of stands offering a variety of mementos..\na lot of restaurants in the area..

587699773.name: Great place ! Nice pedestrian with many options to spend a day
587699773.author: a TripAdvisor user
587699773.reviewBody: Very nice pedestrian in Tlaquepaque. Craft shops, restaurants, bars, ... along the street. \nYou can easily spend a day walking around.

544668200.name: Beautiful pedestrian walkway with cafes, craft shops, and galleries.
544668200.author: a TripAdvisor user
544668200.reviewBody: Great place to enjoy Mexican food and shopping.  Calle Independencia in the artists\' neighborhood of Tlaquepaque is closed to vehicles and serves as an outdoor pedestrian mall.  There are numerous craft shops, restaurants, and fine art galleries.  Lovely Mexican handicrafts and food.  There are also street performers.   Nice place for visitors to stroll and appreciate this lovely Guadalajara neighborhood.  The area is also known for mariachis and Day of the Dead festivities.  I did my Christmas shopping!

515602846.name: Nice place to visit
515602846.author: a TripAdvisor user
515602846.reviewBody: There isn\'t much to do, but it does have very nice restaurants, with very good Mariachi music. \n\nNice place for a walk and to find some food. Also does have very nice historic buildings for pictures. If you are not eating though, 30 minutes should be enough to see what there is to see.

504560309.name: Not bad place. Horrible directions!
504560309.author: a TripAdvisor user
504560309.reviewBody: I did not ended up going because when I used the directions to get there using UBER, the map sent me to a really bad neighborhood. It was fairly scary. Immediately changed the destination in UBER and got the hell away from there. At the end, I decided not to go to the actual "Calle Independencia" This directions need to be changed.

465696188.name: A good place to start.
465696188.author: a TripAdvisor user
465696188.reviewBody: Always lots of things happen along any street named Independencia - just take a taxi there and get out and walk - things

448039936.name: One of the nicest street to visit
448039936.author: a TripAdvisor user
448039936.reviewBody:
This street, in Tlaquepaqe has a lot of galleries.
The galleries are huge, some of them just looks small from the outside.
The prices are fair and the total atmosphere is great. 
start from El Parian center.

434611006.name: Incredible art in a peaceful setting
434611006.author: a TripAdvisor user
434611006.reviewBody: Calle Independencia provides a showplace for art furniture, jewelry, and other mediums. Most of the products are made in nearby Tonala where you can buy them for a much cheaper price. However, I\'m not all that mobile and Tonala is dusty and loaded with chaos and trucks, so Calle Indenpendencia works for me. Great restaurants, too. You can watch artists as you walk along and also in restaurants. A potter works in El Patio.

409052171.name: Real Taste of Mexico Culture
409052171.author: a TripAdvisor user
409052171.reviewBody: Excellent to stroll and spend an entire afternoon. Window shopping and having a Margarita and any of the \ntypical restaurants on this street. All shops and most rest close early. (Around 9 PM ). In general I found it to be a safe area.

398784315.name: Centro Historico and calle Independencia
398784315.author: a TripAdvisor user
398784315.reviewBody: Great area for walking around and chacking out the little stoes and restaurants. This street is very clost the cetral plazas and historical buldings. Easy walking and lots to see.

392890247.name: Something for Everyone
392890247.author: a TripAdvisor user
392890247.reviewBody: This is a great pedestrian walkway with a wide variety of shops, galleries, and restaurants.  From cheesy tourist merchandise to high end galleries, it has something for everyone.  Nice places to sit and people watch as well. This is a place that you can walk down a few times and always find something new.. Enjoy.

389507424.name: Beautiful!
389507424.author: a TripAdvisor user
389507424.reviewBody: Fun to walk along and see the history and shops along the way. There are lots of little shops and food stalls, as well as plenty of pretty plants to view and opportunities to take great photos!

380399600.name: Like traveling back in time
380399600.author: a TripAdvisor user
380399600.reviewBody: Spent many an hour walking and just enjoying the wonderful weather and the architecture here. People are amazingly warm too.

367286190.name: Never miss
367286190.author: a TripAdvisor user
367286190.reviewBody: All our visitors love Tlacapaque and the pedestrian center, Calle Independencia. Try to arrive after 10 in the morning so you can shop and go to the pottery museum. Then enjoy one of the wonderful restaurants.

354204016.name: I love downtown Guadalajara.
354204016.author: a TripAdvisor user
354204016.reviewBody: I love walking around along Calle Independencia, specially noticing the buildings surrounding the street. They have done an excellent job keeping the place looking neat, without stealing from the Colonial style that the hundred year old buildings have.

326146105.name: Excellent shopping
326146105.author: a TripAdvisor user
326146105.reviewBody: Find your way to this street and you will not be disappointed.  There is a feast for the eyes in the different shopping experiences, ceramics, clothes, leather goods, etc

226486328.name: It is nice, but one can see lots of streets like this one.
226486328.author: a TripAdvisor user
226486328.reviewBody: It was actually very nice, but nice is nice. Once can see lots of nice. Take a look if you are close by, or stop in any neighborhood that looks nice to you. Do not make a special trip and one need not spend more than an hour or two there.

224916254.name: In need of a new wave of creativity
224916254.author: a TripAdvisor user
224916254.reviewBody: Independencia is a lovely day out as it has always been, but like many art centres, it is going through a transition period at the moment. When I was last there, about 7 years ago, there were many more artisan shops with a wider creative palate than there are today. Now, there are many shops which are selling similar things, and there are a growing number of restaurants vs. non-food establishments. The area as a whole continues to get infrastructure upgrades, which is welcome. If you are in Guadalajara, do visit; it is one of the prettier areas of the metropolitan area, and there are some real gems, both with regard to food and the arts.

195096633.name: It Is What It Is
195096633.author: a TripAdvisor user
195096633.reviewBody: Another year goes by and once again, it was time for a Mexico visit.  While I still stand by my comments of a year ago, the commercial landscape continues to change but the number of changes are fewer this year.  The locals continue to come out in droves in the evenings and on weekends to enjoy the area.  More positive for Tlaquepaque were the greatly increased numbers of foreign visitors we saw this year versus the past couple of years.\n\nIt remains a safe area to stay, shop, and enjoy!

190954596.name: Great day trip
190954596.author: a TripAdvisor user
190954596.reviewBody: We really enjoyed our day in the shopping district of Tlaquepaque. The stores were interesting to look at, some very stunning art galleries \\ furniture stores to walk though, and the street itself is great for people watching while sitting in one of the many restaurants. That said, it didn\'t feel like an artisan\'s shopping area, more a high priced block catering to day visitors and tourists. All in all, a great day trip but not going to be a regular excursion.

159957558.name: Things are Changing
159957558.author: a TripAdvisor user
159957558.reviewBody: We have been noticing gradual changes for a number of years but really noticed a character change this past February.  The number of good shops and galleries have been reduced greatly and replaced by more restaurants, coffee shops and other establishments which might appeal to the casual daily visitor.  Many of the spaces are owned by families or investors that seem to care only what they can earn in rental revenue.  It is our understanding that rents have become prohibitive for the average shop or gallery.  If things follow a somewhat typical pattern for Mexico, we will probably see constant turnover and most likely a cleansing of many of the newer less extablished restaurants down the road.\n\nThe fine reputation of Tlaquepaque as a center for quality arts and crafts may be in serious jeopardy in years to come.  Hopefully someone will recognize the negative trend and take positive steps to turn things around!

135935256.name: Beautiful place for Guadalajara
135935256.author: a TripAdvisor user
135935256.reviewBody: This is a great place to visit, but the shopping is not the best. The stores are very astheticslly appealing, but the wares leave a lot to be desired. If you are buying big pieces of art, textiles, or furniture for a house then it is a good place. Tlaquepaque is a town of ceramic artisans, but there is not a well curated selection in the shops. I always stay at Casa de las Flores and they have an AMAZING collection of ceramics. I was told they are opening a shop and I would reccomendthat you go there. They will be more expensive, but the quality is amazing and they do the work of finding the best pieces for you. They have a shop for guests and I always buy something because he has the best stuff, he is true collector. ( just like Zocalo in Patzcuro, but he is closed now :()\n\nThe street is a nice reprieve from the streets of Guadalajara. Very pleasant to stroll down. Other than Sergio Bustamonte\'s shop on Independencia, I like the shops a few streets over.And there is an ice cream shop with the best ice cream in Mexico off the beaten path. I forget the name, but there are always long lines, so you will know it when you see it. Get the nutella ice cream!

133337893.name: A must in Tlaquepaque
133337893.author: a TripAdvisor user
133337893.reviewBody: It is the hart and soul of Tlaquepaque, a nice walk and do go inside different shops...

131705775.name: Go as far as you can
131705775.author: a TripAdvisor user
131705775.reviewBody: to spot the truly unique works of art that wait for you at the end.  You\'ll know what I mean when you get there - large, touchable and mind-blowing!

131195990.name: NOT in Guadalajara in tlaquepaque! And not called Calle Idependencia; Plaza Parian
131195990.author: a TripAdvisor user
131195990.reviewBody: Once we got the suburb correct which took us awhile because the taxi did not recognize Calle Independencia nor the hotel staff, because it\'s not known by the street, apparently there are several streets named this in all suburbs. This is Plaza Parian in Tlaquepaque. The city name needs to be changed to Tlaquepaque.\nAmazing !!!! All reviews are correct! A MUST VISIT! We visited twice during our stay.

126969537.name: If you visit ONE predestrian street in Mexico, this is it.
126969537.author: a TripAdvisor user
126969537.reviewBody: A gorgeous pedestrian street that has everything: small traditional shops, beautiful upscale shops that sell jewellery, antiques and fabulous household items, a nice pottery museums, cafes and restaurants, and ends up in the center of town. The beauty of Tlaquepaque is that it is no Disneyland ... people live and work in this beautiful town. Favourite stops are: Adobe (a shop that sells quality mexican crafts and a good restaurant under one roof), Galeria Sergio Bustamante (fantastic jewels and sculpture), Real San Pedro (new restaurant, good quality food, good environment), Rodo Padilla shop (the famous "chubby guys" ceramics). Can\u00b4t miss this street! We locals go for a nice stroll , nice meal and a hand made ice cream sold by a guy impecably dressed in ranch clothes and a hat.

124981173.name: Our friends love this shopping street
124981173.author: a TripAdvisor user
124981173.reviewBody: This pedestrian street is a visual delight, and it\'s packed with restaurants, shops, and galleries, ranging from colorful souvenir stands to the high-end gallery of artist/sculptor Sergio Bustamante. Stop in to see the Ceramic Museum (free). When guests come to visit us in Mexico, they always enjoy a stroll along Calle Independencia.

123416893.name: THE street of Tlaquepaque
123416893.author: a TripAdvisor user
123416893.reviewBody: Nice and quiet stroll on this pedestrian street. Many art boutiques.\nJust for this a good reason to get out of the center of Guadalajara. Bus 275 or 647 from GDL Centro is only 15-20 minutes.

123265931.name: Calle Independencia
123265931.author: a TripAdvisor user
123265931.reviewBody: A street is a street and that is what this is...just another of the many streets.

122517980.name: Very lively especially around Christmas time
122517980.author: a TripAdvisor user
122517980.reviewBody: A nice traffic free street. Stands everywhere. But here are better places to visit

122206455.name: Love it
122206455.author: a TripAdvisor user

122045830.name: Most visited tourist street in the metropolitan area.
122045830.author: a TripAdvisor user
122045830.reviewBody: Good stores, art and antique galleries and restaurants. Probably the most "Mexican" part of Guadalajara. Real San Pedro restaurant and Casa Fuerte are my two favorite restaurants. The stores change frequently.

121175721.reviewBody: love the fact that u will find very close to it a bunch of stand with great merchandise and very affordable believe me.

118696197.name: A must day of shopping for any Mexico trip
118696197.author: a TripAdvisor user
118696197.reviewBody: Over ten plus years of visiting Mexico and Tlaquepaque is a must for a day of shopping.  Most of the shops are located in old haciendas and are a cultural tour in themselves.  As a previous poster stated, Calle Independencia is pedestrian only but one has to pay attention when crossing the cross streets.

22300646.name: Best shopping street in Tlaquepaque
22300646.author: a TripAdvisor user
22300646.reviewBody: If you are going to Tlaquepaque, Calle Independencia is probably the most fun to shop at - as it is closed off to traffic! The stores are the most upscale in Tlaquepaque - lots of designers and custom made stores. The best restaurants are also located along this street. There is another street, that is parallel to Independencia - the main street coming in - that is open to traffic that also has great stores. Those two streets are the best for a day of shopping.
